verses.text: Since many have undertaken to compile a narrative concerning the events that have been fulfilled among us,
just as those who were eyewitnesses from the beginning and became servants of the word handed them down to us,
it seemed good to me also, having followed all things closely from the start with precision, to write to you in an orderly manner, most excellent Theophilus,
so that you may know with certainty the things about which you have been instructed.
In the days of Herod, king of Judea, there was a certain priest named Zechariah, of the priestly division of Abijah, and he had a wife from the daughters of Aaron, and her name was Elizabeth.
They were both righteous before God, walking blamelessly in all the commandments and ordinances of the Lord.
But they had no child, because Elizabeth was barren, and both were advanced in their years.
Now it happened that while he was serving as priest before God during his division's turn of duty,
according to the custom of the priesthood, he was chosen by lot to enter the sanctuary of the Lord and burn incense.
And the whole multitude of the people was praying outside at the hour of incense.
Then an angel of the Lord appeared to him, standing at the right side of the altar of incense.
And Zechariah was troubled when he saw him, and fear fell upon him.
But the angel said to him, "Do not be afraid, Zechariah, for your petition has been heard, and your wife Elizabeth will bear you a son, and you shall call his name John.
He will be a joy and delight to you, and many will rejoice at his birth.
For he will be great before the Lord. Wine and strong drink he shall never drink, and he will be filled with the Holy Spirit while still in his mother's womb.
He will turn many of the sons of Israel back to the Lord their God.

And he will go before him in the spirit and power of Elijah, to turn the hearts of fathers toward their children and the disobedient to the wisdom of the righteous—to prepare for the Lord a people made ready."
And Zechariah said to the angel, "By what will I know this? For I am an old man, and my wife is advanced in her years."
And the angel answered and said to him, "I am Gabriel, who stands in the presence of God, and I was sent to speak to you and to bring you this good news.
And behold, you will be silent and unable to speak until the day these things come to pass, because you did not believe my words, which will be fulfilled in their appointed time."
Meanwhile, the people were waiting for Zechariah, and they were wondering at his delay in the sanctuary.
When he came out, he was unable to speak to them, and they realized that he had seen a vision in the sanctuary. He kept making signs to them and remained mute.
And when the days of his service were completed, he went home.
After these days, his wife Elizabeth conceived, and she kept herself hidden for five months, saying,
"This is what the Lord has done for me in the days when he looked upon me to take away my disgrace among people."
In the sixth month, the angel Gabriel was sent from God to a town in Galilee named Nazareth,
to a virgin betrothed to a man whose name was Joseph, of the house of David. The virgin's name was Mary.
And coming to her, he said, "Rejoice, graced one! The Lord is with you."
But she was deeply troubled by his words and pondered what kind of greeting this might be.
The angel said to her, "Do not be afraid, Mary, for you have found favor with God.
And behold, you will conceive in your womb and bear a son, and you shall call his name Jesus.
He will be great and will be called Son of the Most High, and the Lord God will give him the throne of his father David.
He will reign over the house of Jacob forever, and of his kingdom there will be no end."
Mary said to the angel, "How will this be, since I have not known a man?"
The angel answered her, "The Holy Spirit will come upon you, and the power of the Most High will overshadow you. Therefore the holy one to be born will be called Son of God.
And behold, your relative Elizabeth—she too has conceived a son in her old age, and this is the sixth month for her who was called barren.
For no word from God will be impossible."
Mary said, "Behold, the slave of the Lord. Let it happen to me according to your word." And the angel departed from her.
In those days Mary arose and went with haste into the hill country, to a town of Judah,
and she entered the house of Zechariah and greeted Elizabeth.
And when Elizabeth heard Mary's greeting, the infant leaped in her womb. Elizabeth was filled with the Holy Spirit,
and she cried out with a loud voice and said, "Blessed are you among women, and blessed is the fruit of your womb!
And why is this granted to me, that the mother of my Lord should come to me?
For behold, when the sound of your greeting came to my ears, the infant leaped for joy in my womb.
And blessed is she who believed that there will be a fulfillment of what was spoken to her from the Lord."
And Mary said: "My soul magnifies the Lord,
and my spirit has rejoiced in God my Savior,
for he has looked upon the lowliness of his slave. For behold, from now on all generations will call me blessed,
for the Mighty One has done great things for me, and holy is his name.
His mercy extends to generation after generation for those who fear him.
He has shown strength with his arm; he has scattered the arrogant in the thoughts of their hearts.
He has brought down rulers from their thrones and lifted up the lowly.
He has filled the hungry with good things, and the rich he has sent away empty.
He has helped Israel his servant, remembering his mercy,
just as he spoke to our fathers, to Abraham and to his offspring forever."
Mary stayed with her about three months and then returned to her home.
Now the time came for Elizabeth to give birth, and she bore a son.
Her neighbors and relatives heard that the Lord had shown his great mercy to her, and they rejoiced with her.
On the eighth day they came to circumcise the child, and they were going to name him Zechariah after his father.
But his mother answered, "No! He shall be called John."
They said to her, "There is no one among your relatives who is called by this name."
So they made signs to his father, asking what he wanted him to be called.
He asked for a writing tablet and wrote, "His name is John." And everyone was amazed.
Immediately his mouth was opened and his tongue freed, and he began to speak, blessing God.
Fear came upon all who lived around them, and throughout the entire hill country of Judea all these things were being talked about.
All who heard them laid them up in their hearts, saying, "What then will this child become?" For indeed the hand of the Lord was with him.
And his father Zechariah was filled with the Holy Spirit and prophesied, saying:
"Blessed be the Lord, the God of Israel, for he has visited and brought about redemption for his people.
He has raised up a horn of salvation for us in the house of David his servant,
just as he spoke through the mouth of his holy prophets from of old—
salvation from our enemies and from the hand of all who hate us,
to show mercy to our fathers and to remember his holy covenant,
the oath that he swore to Abraham our father, to grant us
that we, having been rescued from the hand of our enemies, might serve him without fear,
in holiness and righteousness before him all our days.
And you, child, will be called a prophet of the Most High, for you will go before the Lord to prepare his ways,
to give knowledge of salvation to his people through the forgiveness of their sins,
because of the compassionate mercy of our God, by which the dawn from on high will visit us,
to shine upon those sitting in darkness and in the shadow of death, to guide our feet into the way of peace."
The child grew and became strong in spirit, and he was in the wilderness until the day of his public appearance to Israel.

chapters.notes:
**"Graced one" (v. 28)**: The Greek κεχαριτωμένη is a perfect passive participle from χαριτόω, meaning "one who has been graced/favored." This creates wordplay with χαῖρε ("rejoice") and χάρις ("grace/favor" in v. 30) that is impossible to fully preserve in English. "Graced one" attempts to retain the verbal connection better than the traditional "favored one."

**"Slave" (v. 38, 48)**: Greek δούλη is consistently rendered "slave" rather than "servant" or "handmaid." In the ancient Mediterranean context, δοῦλος/δούλη specifically meant a slave—someone with no autonomous rights who belonged entirely to their master. Mary's self-designation is a profound statement of complete availability to God's purposes.

**"Strong drink" (v. 15)**: Greek σίκερα is a Semitic loanword (Hebrew שֵׁכָר) referring to fermented beverages other than grape wine. The prohibition echoes the Nazirite vow (Numbers 6:3).

**"Overshadow" (v. 35)**: Greek ἐπισκιάζω carries connotations of divine presence, evoking the cloud that overshadowed the tabernacle (Exodus 40:35 LXX uses the same verb). This is not language of sexual conception but of God's glory taking up residence.

**"No word from God will be impossible" (v. 37)**: The Greek ῥῆμα means both "word" and "thing/matter." The statement echoes Genesis 18:14 LXX (regarding Sarah's conception) and intentionally carries the double meaning: every divine word will be accomplished; nothing is impossible for God.

**"Compassionate mercy" (v. 78)**: Greek σπλάγχνα ἐλέους literally means "intestines/bowels of mercy"—the ancients located deep emotion in the gut. "Compassionate mercy" attempts to convey the visceral, deeply felt nature of God's mercy.

**"Dawn from on high" (v. 78)**: Greek ἀνατολή means "rising" and can refer to the sunrise or to a branch/shoot. It likely carries messianic overtones (cf. Zechariah 3:8; 6:12 LXX, where ἀνατολή translates the Hebrew צֶמַח "Branch"). "Dawn" captures the light imagery that continues in v. 79.

**"Public appearance" (v. 80)**: Greek ἀναδείξεως refers to a formal presentation or commissioning for public service, not merely "appearing" in a casual sense.

verses.text: Now it happened in those days that a decree went out from Caesar Augustus that all the inhabited world should be registered.
(This was the first registration, when Quirinius was governing Syria.)
And everyone was traveling to be registered, each to his own city.
Joseph also went up from Galilee, from the town of Nazareth, into Judea, to the city of David which is called Bethlehem, because he was from the house and lineage of David,
to be registered with Mary, who was betrothed to him, and was pregnant.
And it happened that while they were there, the days for her to give birth were completed,
and she gave birth to her son, the firstborn. She wrapped him in strips of cloth and laid him in a feeding trough, because there was no room for them in the guest quarters.
And there were shepherds in that same region, living out in the fields and keeping night watches over their flock.
And a messenger of the Lord appeared to them, and the glory of the Lord shone all around them, and they were terrified.
And the messenger said to them, "Do not be afraid! For look—I am announcing good news to you of a great joy that will be for all the people:
Today a savior has been born for you in the city of David, who is the Anointed One, the Lord.
And this will be the sign for you: you will find an infant wrapped in strips of cloth and lying in a feeding trough."
And suddenly there appeared with the messenger a multitude of the heavenly army, praising God and saying:
"Glory to God in the highest realms, and on earth peace among people of his favor."

And it happened that when the messengers had departed from them into heaven, the shepherds were saying to one another, "Let us go now to Bethlehem and see this thing that has happened, which the Lord has made known to us."
And they went in haste and found Mary and Joseph, and the infant lying in the feeding trough.
And having seen, they made known the message that had been spoken to them about this child.
And all who heard it were amazed at what the shepherds told them.
But Mary was treasuring all these things, pondering them in her heart.
And the shepherds returned, glorifying and praising God for all that they had heard and seen, just as it had been told to them.
And when eight days were completed for his circumcision, he was named Jesus—the name given by the messenger before he was conceived in the womb.
And when the days of their purification according to the law of Moses were completed, they brought him up to Jerusalem to present him to the Lord
(as it is written in the law of the Lord: "Every male who opens the womb shall be called holy to the Lord")
and to offer a sacrifice according to what is stated in the law of the Lord: "a pair of turtledoves or two young pigeons."
And look—there was a man in Jerusalem whose name was Simeon. This man was righteous and devout, waiting for the consolation of Israel, and the Holy Spirit was upon him.
It had been revealed to him by the Holy Spirit that he would not see death before he had seen the Lord's Anointed.
And he came in the Spirit into the temple courts. And when the parents brought in the child Jesus to do for him what was customary according to the law,
Simeon received him into his arms and blessed God and said:
"Now you are releasing your slave, Master, according to your word, in peace,
for my eyes have seen your salvation,
which you have prepared before the face of all peoples:
a light for revelation to the nations, and glory for your people Israel."
And his father and mother were marveling at what was being said about him.
And Simeon blessed them and said to Mary his mother, "Look—this one is appointed for the falling and rising of many in Israel, and as a sign to be opposed
(and a sword will pierce through your own soul), so that the thoughts of many hearts may be revealed."
And there was Anna, a prophetess, daughter of Phanuel, from the tribe of Asher. She was greatly advanced in years, having lived with a husband for seven years from her virginity,
and then as a widow until she was eighty-four. She never left the temple, worshiping with fastings and prayers night and day.
And at that very hour she came up and began giving thanks to God, and she spoke about him to all who were waiting for the redemption of Jerusalem.
And when they had completed everything according to the law of the Lord, they returned to Galilee, to their own town of Nazareth.
And the child was growing and becoming strong, being filled with wisdom, and the favor of God was upon him.
Now his parents used to travel to Jerusalem every year for the feast of Passover.
And when he was twelve years old, they went up according to the custom of the feast.
And when the days were completed, as they were returning, the boy Jesus stayed behind in Jerusalem, and his parents did not know it.
Supposing him to be in the traveling company, they went a day's journey and began searching for him among their relatives and acquaintances.
And not finding him, they returned to Jerusalem, searching for him.
And it happened that after three days they found him in the temple courts, sitting among the teachers, both listening to them and asking them questions.
And all who heard him were astonished at his understanding and his answers.
When they saw him, they were overwhelmed, and his mother said to him, "Child, why have you done this to us? Look—your father and I have been searching for you in anguish!"
And he said to them, "Why were you searching for me? Did you not know that I must be in the place of my Father?"
But they did not understand the word he spoke to them.
And he went down with them and came to Nazareth, and was obedient to them. And his mother treasured all these things in her heart.
And Jesus continued to advance in wisdom and maturity, and in favor with God and people.

chapters.notes:
**"Guest quarters" (v. 7)**: The Greek κατάλυμα does not mean "inn" (that would be πανδοχεῖον, which Luke uses in 10:34 for the Good Samaritan parable). It means a guest room or lodging space—the same word Luke uses for the "upper room" of the Last Supper (22:11). The image is of a crowded guest room in a family home, not a commercial establishment turning away customers.

**"Feeding trough" (v. 7, 12, 16)**: φάτνη is literally a manger—a trough from which animals eat. "Manger" has become so sentimentalized in English that "feeding trough" better conveys the stark, humble reality.

**"People of his favor" (v. 14)**: The genitive εὐδοκίας modifies "people," not the clause as a whole. This is not "good will toward men" (KJV, following a variant reading) but "peace among people who have [God's] favor"—those upon whom God's choosing rests.

**"Messenger" (v. 9, 10, 12, 13, 15)**: ἄγγελος literally means "messenger." While "angel" is the traditional rendering, retaining "messenger" keeps the word's fundamental meaning visible and connects to the vocabulary of announcement.

**"The Lord's Anointed" (v. 26)**: τὸν χριστὸν κυρίου is a Septuagintal phrase (cf. 1 Sam 24:6, 10; 26:9, etc.) meaning "the Anointed of the Lord"—the awaited messianic king. This preserves the connection to Israel's royal tradition better than simply "the Christ."

**"Consolation of Israel" (v. 25)**: παράκλησιν echoes Isaiah 40:1 ("Comfort, comfort my people") and its promises of restoration. Simeon is waiting for God to fulfill these prophetic hopes.

**"In the place of my Father" (v. 49)**: ἐν τοῖς τοῦ πατρός μου is genuinely ambiguous—it could mean "in my Father's house," "about my Father's business," or "among my Father's things/affairs." I chose "in the place of my Father" to preserve this productive ambiguity while gesturing at the temple context.

**"Maturity" (v. 52)**: ἡλικία can mean either "age" or "stature." Given the context of growth in wisdom and favor, "maturity" captures both physical and personal development better than either single option.

verses.text: In the fifteenth year of the reign of Tiberius Caesar, while Pontius Pilate was governing Judea, and Herod was tetrarch of Galilee, and his brother Philip was tetrarch of the region of Ituraea and Trachonitis, and Lysanias was tetrarch of Abilene,
during the high priesthood of Annas and Caiaphas, the word of God came upon John the son of Zechariah in the wilderness.
And he went into the whole region around the Jordan, proclaiming a baptism of repentance for the release of sins,
as it is written in the book of the words of Isaiah the prophet: A voice crying out in the wilderness: "Prepare the way of the Lord, make his paths straight.
Every ravine will be filled in, and every mountain and hill will be brought low, and the crooked ways will become straight, and the rough roads smooth—
and all flesh will see the salvation of God."
So he would say to the crowds coming out to be baptized by him: "Brood of vipers! Who warned you to flee from the coming wrath?
Produce fruit worthy of repentance, and do not begin saying among yourselves, 'We have Abraham as our father.' For I tell you that God is able from these stones to raise up children for Abraham.
Even now the axe lies at the root of the trees. Every tree that does not produce good fruit is cut down and thrown into fire."
And the crowds kept asking him, "What then should we do?"
He answered them, "Let the one who has two tunics share with the one who has none, and let the one who has food do the same."
Tax collectors also came to be baptized, and they said to him, "Teacher, what should we do?"
He said to them, "Collect nothing more than what has been prescribed for you."
Soldiers too were asking him, "And what should we do?" And he said to them, "Do not extort money by threats, do not bring false accusations, and be content with your wages."
Now while the people were waiting in expectation, and all were pondering in their hearts concerning John—whether he might be the Messiah—
John answered, saying to all: "I baptize you with water, but one more powerful than I is coming, the strap of whose sandals I am not worthy to untie. He will baptize you in the Holy Spirit and fire.
His winnowing shovel is in his hand to clear his threshing floor and to gather the wheat into his storehouse, but the chaff he will burn with unquenchable fire."
So with many other exhortations he proclaimed good news to the people.
But Herod the tetrarch, having been rebuked by him concerning Herodias his brother's wife, and concerning all the evil things Herod had done,
added this to them all: he locked John up in prison.
Now when all the people were being baptized, and when Jesus had been baptized and was praying, the heaven was opened,
and the Holy Spirit descended upon him in bodily form like a dove. And a voice came from heaven: "You are my Son, the beloved; in you I delight."
Jesus himself was about thirty years old when he began, being the son—as was thought—of Joseph, son of Heli,
son of Matthat, son of Levi, son of Melchi, son of Jannai, son of Joseph,
son of Mattathias, son of Amos, son of Nahum, son of Esli, son of Naggai,
son of Maath, son of Mattathias, son of Semein, son of Josech, son of Joda,
son of Joanan, son of Rhesa, son of Zerubbabel, son of Shealtiel, son of Neri,
son of Melchi, son of Addi, son of Cosam, son of Elmadam, son of Er,
son of Joshua, son of Eliezer, son of Jorim, son of Matthat, son of Levi,
son of Simeon, son of Judah, son of Joseph, son of Jonam, son of Eliakim,
son of Melea, son of Menna, son of Mattatha, son of Nathan, son of David,
son of Jesse, son of Obed, son of Boaz, son of Sala, son of Nahshon,
son of Amminadab, son of Admin, son of Arni, son of Hezron, son of Perez, son of Judah,
son of Jacob, son of Isaac, son of Abraham, son of Terah, son of Nahor,
son of Serug, son of Reu, son of Peleg, son of Eber, son of Shelah,
son of Cainan, son of Arphaxad, son of Shem, son of Noah, son of Lamech,
son of Methuselah, son of Enoch, son of Jared, son of Mahalaleel, son of Cainan,
son of Enosh, son of Seth, son of Adam, son of God.

chapters.notes:
**"The word of God came upon John" (v. 2)**: The phrase ἐγένετο ῥῆμα θεοῦ ἐπὶ echoes the prophetic call narratives of the Hebrew scriptures (cf. Jeremiah 1:1; Hosea 1:1). Luke deliberately presents John's ministry using the vocabulary of prophetic commissioning.

**"Release of sins" (v. 3)**: Greek ἄφεσις means release, letting go, remission. "Forgiveness" works, but "release" better captures the sense of liberation from bondage that ἄφεσις carries, particularly in light of the Isaiah quotation that follows with its themes of preparation and making straight.

**"Brood of vipers" (v. 7)**: γεννήματα ἐχιδνῶν—literally "offspring of vipers." "Brood" captures both the biological sense and the collective nature of the accusation.

**"Do not extort money by threats" (v. 14)**: Greek διασείω literally means "shake violently"—a vivid image of the physical intimidation soldiers could use to extract money. "Shake down" is the closest English idiom but somewhat informal; I opted for a more explicit rendering.

**"Bring false accusations" (v. 14)**: Greek συκοφαντέω referred to making malicious accusations to gain advantage—a particular temptation for soldiers who could bring charges against civilians.

**"In you I delight" (v. 22)**: Greek εὐδόκησα is aorist, but likely functions as a timeless expression of divine pleasure. "I delight" captures this better than the more static "I am well pleased" and echoes the language of Isaiah 42:1.

**"When he began" (v. 23)**: The Greek ἀρχόμενος ("beginning") likely refers to the beginning of Jesus's public ministry. The word stands somewhat awkwardly without an explicit object, but the meaning is clear from context.

**The genealogy's conclusion (v. 38)**: Luke traces Jesus's lineage back through Adam to God (τοῦ θεοῦ), a distinctive feature absent from Matthew's genealogy. This emphasizes Jesus's connection to all humanity, not just Israel—consistent with Luke's universal emphasis.

verses.text: Now Jesus, full of the Holy Spirit, returned from the Jordan and was being led by the Spirit in the wilderness
for forty days, being tested by the slanderer. He ate nothing during those days, and when they were completed, he was hungry.
The slanderer said to him, "If you are the Son of God, tell this stone to become bread."
Jesus answered him, "It stands written: 'A person shall not live on bread alone.'"
And leading him up, he showed him all the kingdoms of the inhabited world in a single instant.
The slanderer said to him, "To you I will give all this authority and their glory, because it has been handed over to me, and I give it to whomever I wish.
So if you worship before me, it will all be yours."
And Jesus answered him, "It stands written: 'You shall worship the Lord your God, and him alone shall you serve.'"
Then he led him to Jerusalem and set him on the wing of the temple and said to him, "If you are the Son of God, throw yourself down from here,
for it stands written: 'He will command his angels concerning you, to guard you,'
and 'On their hands they will bear you up, lest you strike your foot against a stone.'"
And Jesus answered him, "It has been said: 'You shall not put the Lord your God to the test.'"
When the slanderer had completed every test, he withdrew from him until an opportune moment.
Jesus returned to Galilee in the power of the Spirit, and news about him spread throughout the whole surrounding region.
He was teaching in their synagogues, being praised by everyone.
He came to Nazara, where he had been raised. On the Sabbath day, as was his custom, he entered the synagogue and stood up to read.
The scroll of the prophet Isaiah was handed to him, and unrolling the scroll, he found the place where it was written:

"The Spirit of the Lord is upon me, because he has anointed me to bring good news to the poor. He has sent me to proclaim release to captives and recovery of sight to the blind, to send forth the oppressed in freedom,
to proclaim the year of the Lord's favor."
Rolling up the scroll, he gave it back to the attendant and sat down. And the eyes of everyone in the synagogue were fixed intently on him.
He began to say to them, "Today this scripture has been fulfilled in your hearing."
Everyone was speaking well of him and marveling at the gracious words coming from his mouth. They were saying, "Is this not Joseph's son?"
He said to them, "No doubt you will quote this proverb to me: 'Physician, heal yourself! Whatever we heard happened in Capernaum, do here also in your hometown.'"
Then he said, "Truly I tell you, no prophet is welcome in his hometown.
But in truth I tell you, there were many widows in Israel in the days of Elijah, when the sky was shut for three years and six months and a great famine came over all the land,
yet Elijah was sent to none of them except to a widow at Zarephath in the region of Sidon.
And there were many lepers in Israel in the time of Elisha the prophet, yet none of them was cleansed except Naaman the Syrian."
When they heard this, everyone in the synagogue was filled with fury.
They rose up and drove him out of the city and led him to the brow of the hill on which their city was built, intending to throw him off the cliff.
But he passed through the midst of them and went on his way.
He went down to Capernaum, a city of Galilee, and was teaching them on the Sabbaths.
They were astonished at his teaching, because his word carried authority.
In the synagogue there was a man who had the spirit of an unclean demon, and he cried out with a loud voice,
"Ha! What is there between us and you, Jesus of Nazareth? Have you come to destroy us? I know who you are—the Holy One of God!"
Jesus rebuked it, saying, "Be silent and come out of him!" And throwing the man down in their midst, the demon came out of him without harming him.
Astonishment fell upon everyone, and they were saying to one another, "What is this word? With authority and power he commands the unclean spirits, and they come out!"
And the report about him was spreading into every place in the surrounding region.
Rising from the synagogue, he entered the house of Simon. Now Simon's mother-in-law was in the grip of a severe fever, and they asked him about her.
Standing over her, he rebuked the fever, and it released her. Immediately she got up and began serving them.
As the sun was setting, all who had anyone sick with various diseases brought them to him. Laying his hands on each one of them, he was healing them.
Demons also were coming out of many, crying out and saying, "You are the Son of God!" But rebuking them, he would not allow them to speak, because they knew him to be the Christ.
When day came, he went out and traveled to a deserted place. The crowds were searching for him, and they came to where he was and tried to keep him from leaving them.
But he said to them, "I must bring the good news of the kingdom of God to the other cities also, because for this I was sent."
And he was proclaiming in the synagogues of Judea.

chapters.notes:
**"The slanderer" (vv. 2, 3, 6, 13)**: Greek διάβολος literally means "one who throws across"—a slanderer, false accuser, or one who deceives. "Devil" derives from this word but has accumulated connotations that may obscure the accusatory function. "Slanderer" preserves the semantic force.

**"It stands written" (vv. 4, 8, 10)**: The Greek perfect γέγραπται indicates completed action with ongoing effect—the scripture was written and remains authoritatively in force. "It is written" is adequate, but "it stands written" better captures this continuing authority.

**"In a single instant" (v. 5)**: ἐν στιγμῇ χρόνου—στιγμή is a point or prick (like a punctuation mark), the smallest conceivable unit. "Moment" is too vague; this emphasizes the supernatural instantaneity.

**"Opportune moment" (v. 13)**: ἄχρι καιροῦ—καιρός denotes not mere time (χρόνος) but a significant, fitting occasion. Luke signals the devil's strategic withdrawal and anticipated return at Jesus's passion.

**"Nazara" (v. 16)**: Preserving the form in the Greek text rather than standardizing to "Nazareth."

**"In your hearing" (v. 21)**: Literally "in your ears" (ἐν τοῖς ὠσὶν ὑμῶν). The idiom emphasizes that fulfillment occurs in the very act of their hearing Jesus read it.

**"What is there between us and you?" (v. 34)**: τί ἡμῖν καὶ σοί is a Semitic idiom (cf. Hebrew מַה־לָּנוּ וָלָךְ) expressing protest or rejection of involvement. It could mean "What have we to do with you?" or "Why are you interfering with us?"

**"In the grip of" (v. 38)**: συνεχομένη conveys being seized, constrained, or oppressed—stronger than merely "suffering from."

**"Rebuked the fever" (v. 39)**: Luke uses ἐπετίμησεν (the same verb used for demons in v. 35) for Jesus's treatment of the fever, suggesting Luke understood illness as having a quasi-personal, hostile character that Jesus confronted with authoritative command.

**"Judea" (v. 44)**: The earliest manuscripts read "Judea," though contextually Galilee seems expected. Following the critical text, understanding "Judea" here perhaps in the broader sense of "Jewish territory" or as Luke's anticipatory focus on Jerusalem.

verses.text: Now it happened that as the crowd was pressing in on him to hear the word of God, he was standing beside the lake of Gennesaret.
He saw two boats moored at the edge of the lake; the fishermen had gotten out of them and were washing their nets.
Getting into one of the boats, which belonged to Simon, he asked him to push out a little from the shore. Then, sitting down, he taught the crowds from the boat.
When he finished speaking, he said to Simon, "Push out into the deep water and let down your nets for a catch."
Simon answered, "Master, we labored through the whole night and caught nothing. But at your word, I will let down the nets."
When they did this, they enclosed such a great quantity of fish that their nets were beginning to tear.
They signaled to their partners in the other boat to come and help them. They came, and they filled both boats so full that they were starting to sink.
When Simon Peter saw this, he fell at Jesus's knees, saying, "Depart from me, Lord, for I am a sinful man!"
For astonishment had seized him and all those with him at the catch of fish they had taken,
and likewise James and John, sons of Zebedee, who were partners with Simon. And Jesus said to Simon, "Do not be afraid. From now on you will be catching people alive."
And when they had brought the boats to shore, they left everything and followed him.

Now it happened that while he was in one of the towns, there was a man covered with a skin disease. When he saw Jesus, he fell on his face and begged him, saying, "Lord, if you are willing, you are able to make me clean."
And stretching out his hand, Jesus touched him, saying, "I am willing. Be cleansed." And immediately the disease left him.
Then he ordered him to tell no one: "But go, show yourself to the priest and bring the offering for your purification, just as Moses commanded, as evidence to them."
Yet the report about him spread all the more, and large crowds gathered to hear him and to be healed of their illnesses.
But he would withdraw to desolate places and pray.

Now it happened on one of those days that he was teaching, and Pharisees and teachers of the law were sitting there—they had come from every village of Galilee and Judea and from Jerusalem. And the power of the Lord was present for him to heal.
And look: men came carrying on a mat a man who was paralyzed, and they were trying to bring him in and place him before Jesus.
But finding no way to bring him in because of the crowd, they went up on the roof and lowered him through the tiles, mat and all, into the middle of the room, right in front of Jesus.
When he saw their faith, he said, "Friend, your sins are forgiven you."
The scribes and the Pharisees began reasoning to themselves, saying, "Who is this man who speaks blasphemies? Who can forgive sins except God alone?"
But Jesus, perceiving their thoughts, responded to them, "Why are you reasoning in your hearts?
Which is easier—to say, 'Your sins are forgiven you,' or to say, 'Rise and walk'?
But so that you may know that the Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive sins"—he said to the paralyzed man—"I say to you, rise, pick up your mat, and go to your home."
And immediately he stood up before them, picked up what he had been lying on, and went to his home, glorifying God.
Astonishment seized them all, and they glorified God and were filled with awe, saying, "We have seen extraordinary things today!"
After this he went out and observed a tax collector named Levi sitting at the customs post, and he said to him, "Follow me."
And leaving everything behind, he rose and began following him.
Then Levi held a great banquet for him in his house, and there was a large crowd of tax collectors and others reclining at table with them.
The Pharisees and their scribes were grumbling at his disciples, saying, "Why do you eat and drink with tax collectors and sinners?"
And Jesus answered them, "Those who are healthy have no need of a physician, but those who are sick do.
I have not come to call the righteous but sinners to repentance."
Then they said to him, "The disciples of John fast frequently and offer prayers, and so do the disciples of the Pharisees, but yours eat and drink."
Jesus said to them, "You cannot make the wedding guests fast while the bridegroom is with them, can you?
But days will come when the bridegroom is taken away from them, and then they will fast in those days."
He also told them a parable: "No one tears a patch from a new garment and puts it on an old garment. If he does, he will have torn the new one, and the patch from the new will not match the old.
And no one puts new wine into old wineskins. If he does, the new wine will burst the skins, and the wine will be spilled, and the skins will be ruined.
Rather, new wine must be put into fresh wineskins.
And no one who has drunk aged wine wants new wine, for he says, 'The aged wine is better.'"

chapters.notes:
**"Master" (v. 5)**: The Greek ἐπιστάτα is Luke's distinctive term (appearing only in his Gospel in the NT). It connotes authority and oversight—someone who is in charge. Other translations use "Master," which I retain here as it captures the sense of recognized authority without the specifically rabbinic overtones of "Rabbi."

**"Catching people alive" (v. 10)**: The Greek ζωγρῶν literally means "catching alive"—the word combines ζωός (alive) with ἀγρέω (to catch). It was used for taking prisoners of war alive rather than killing them. This is more vivid than simply "catching" or "fishing for" people—it suggests capturing for life, not death.

**"Skin disease" (v. 12)**: The Greek λέπρα in the first century encompassed various skin conditions, not just what modern medicine calls Hansen's disease. The man is described as πλήρης λέπρας (full of/covered with the disease), indicating an advanced case that would have made him severely ritually unclean.

**"Friend" (v. 20)**: The Greek Ἄνθρωπε is literally "Man" as a form of address. While some translations render this as "Man" or leave it formal, "Friend" better captures the tone of compassionate directness that Jesus uses here, especially given the context of Jesus seeing the faith of those who brought him.

**"Extraordinary things" (v. 26)**: The Greek παράδοξα means things contrary to expectation (παρά + δόξα)—literally, "things beyond opinion/belief." This captures the paradoxical, expectation-shattering nature of what they witnessed better than simply "strange things" or "remarkable things."

**"Grumbling" (v. 30)**: The Greek ἐγόγγυζον echoes the Septuagint's description of Israel grumbling against Moses in the wilderness. This word choice may be intentional, casting the Pharisees in the role of the complaining Israelites.

**"Wedding guests" (v. 34)**: Literally "sons of the bridal chamber" (υἱοὺς τοῦ νυμφῶνος), a Semitic idiom for those invited to participate in the wedding celebration. The phrase carries connotations of intimate participation in the joy of the occasion.

**"Aged wine is better" (v. 39)**: The Greek χρηστός means "good, pleasant, excellent"—it was a standard term for wine quality. This verse (absent from some manuscripts but present in the SBLGNT) presents the perspective of those accustomed to old ways, who naturally prefer what they know.

verses.text: Now it happened on a Sabbath that he was passing through the grain fields, and his disciples were plucking heads of grain and eating them, rubbing them in their hands.
But some of the Pharisees said, "Why are you doing what is not permitted on the Sabbath?"
And Jesus answered them, "Have you not even read what David did when he was hungry, he and those who were with him—
how he entered the house of God and took the bread of the Presence and ate it and gave it to those with him, which no one is permitted to eat except the priests alone?"
And he said to them, "The Son of Man is lord of the Sabbath."
On another Sabbath he entered the synagogue and was teaching. A man was there whose right hand was withered.
The scribes and the Pharisees were watching him closely to see whether he would heal on the Sabbath, so that they might find grounds to accuse him.
But he knew their thoughts, and he said to the man with the withered hand, "Rise and stand in the middle." And he rose and stood there.
Then Jesus said to them, "I ask you: is it permitted on the Sabbath to do good or to do harm, to save a life or to destroy it?"
And looking around at all of them, he said to him, "Stretch out your hand." He did so, and his hand was restored.
But they were filled with senseless rage and began discussing with one another what they might do to Jesus.
In those days he went out to the mountain to pray, and he spent the whole night in prayer to God.
When day came, he called his disciples and chose twelve from among them, whom he also named apostles:
Simon, whom he also named Peter, and Andrew his brother, and James and John, and Philip and Bartholomew,
and Matthew and Thomas, and James son of Alphaeus and Simon who was called the Zealot,
and Judas son of James, and Judas Iscariot, who became a traitor.
He came down with them and stood on a level place, with a large crowd of his disciples and a great multitude of people from all Judea and Jerusalem and the coastal region of Tyre and Sidon,
who had come to hear him and to be healed of their diseases. Those tormented by unclean spirits were being cured,
and the whole crowd was trying to touch him, because power was going out from him and healing everyone.
And lifting up his eyes to his disciples, he said: "Blessed are you who are poor, for yours is the kingdom of God.
Blessed are you who hunger now, for you will be filled. Blessed are you who weep now, for you will laugh.
Blessed are you when people hate you, and when they exclude you and revile you and cast out your name as evil on account of the Son of Man.
Rejoice on that day and leap for joy, for see—your reward is great in heaven. For their ancestors did the same things to the prophets.
But woe to you who are rich, for you have already received your comfort in full.
Woe to you who are full now, for you will hunger. Woe to you who laugh now, for you will mourn and weep.
Woe to you when all people speak well of you, for their ancestors did the same things to the false prophets.
But I say to you who are listening: Love your enemies, do good to those who hate you,
bless those who curse you, pray for those who mistreat you.
To the one who strikes you on the cheek, offer the other also, and from the one who takes your outer cloak, do not withhold even your tunic.
Give to everyone who asks you, and from the one who takes what is yours, do not demand it back.
And as you want people to do to you, do the same to them.
If you love those who love you, what credit is that to you? Even sinners love those who love them.
And if you do good to those who do good to you, what credit is that to you? Even sinners do the same.
And if you lend to those from whom you expect to receive, what credit is that to you? Even sinners lend to sinners to receive back the same amount.
But love your enemies and do good and lend, expecting nothing in return. Your reward will be great, and you will be sons of the Most High, because he is kind to the ungrateful and the wicked.
Be compassionate, just as your Father is compassionate.
Do not judge, and you will not be judged. Do not condemn, and you will not be condemned. Release others, and you will be released.
Give, and it will be given to you—good measure, pressed down, shaken together, overflowing, will be poured into your lap. For with whatever measure you measure out, it will be measured back to you."
He also told them a parable: "Can a blind person guide a blind person? Will they not both fall into a pit?
A disciple is not above the teacher, but everyone who is fully trained will be like their teacher.
Why do you see the splinter in your brother's eye but fail to notice the beam in your own eye?

How can you say to your brother, 'Brother, let me remove the splinter in your eye,' when you yourself do not see the beam in your own eye? Pretender! First remove the beam from your own eye, and then you will see clearly to remove the splinter from your brother's eye.
For there is no good tree that produces rotten fruit, nor again a rotten tree that produces good fruit.
Each tree is known by its own fruit. For figs are not gathered from thorns, nor are grapes picked from a bramble bush.
The good person brings forth good from the good treasury of the heart, and the evil person brings forth evil from evil. For out of the overflow of the heart the mouth speaks.
Why do you call me 'Lord, Lord' and not do what I say?
Everyone who comes to me and hears my words and does them—I will show you what they are like:
They are like a person building a house who dug deep and laid a foundation on the rock. When a flood came, the river burst against that house but could not shake it, because it had been built well.

But the one who hears and does not act is like a person who built a house on the ground without a foundation. The river burst against it, and immediately it collapsed, and the destruction of that house was great."

chapters.notes:
**"Senseless rage" (v. 11)**: The Greek ἀνοίας literally means "without mind" or "mindlessness." In this context it describes an irrational fury—they were so enraged at Jesus healing someone that they lost their reason. "Senseless rage" captures both the emotional intensity and the irrationality Luke emphasizes.

**"Already received your comfort in full" (v. 24)**: The verb ἀπέχετε is commercial language meaning "paid in full"—the same term used in Matthew 6 for the performers who seek human praise. The rich have already received their receipt; the transaction is closed. "In full" makes explicit what the Greek commercial idiom implies.

**"Credit" (vv. 32-34)**: The Greek χάρις here does not mean "grace" in its theological sense but rather "credit" or "what is praiseworthy"—what puts you in a favorable position. The rhetorical question asks: what is noteworthy or commendable about such love?

**"Release" (v. 37)**: The Greek ἀπολύετε can mean "forgive" but more literally means "release, let go, set free"—the same word used for releasing prisoners. Using "release" preserves this concrete imagery and the reciprocal logic: release others and you will be released.

**"Into your lap" (v. 38)**: The Greek κόλπος refers to the fold of a garment at the chest, used as a pocket or pouch for carrying goods. The image is of grain being measured out so generously that it overflows into the folds of one's clothing.

**"Pretender" (v. 42)**: The Greek ὑποκριτά originally meant "actor" or "one who plays a part." The modern English "hypocrite" has shifted to mean someone who believes one thing and does another, but Jesus's critique is about performing a role—pretending to see clearly while actually blind. "Pretender" recovers some of this theatrical sense.

**"Treasury of the heart" (v. 45)**: The Greek θησαυρός means "storehouse" or "treasury"—a place where valuable things are kept. The image is of the heart as a storehouse from which one draws what has been accumulated there.

**"Overflow" (v. 45)**: The Greek περίσσευμα means "abundance" or "surplus"—what spills over because there is more than can be contained. Speech reveals what the heart is full of.

verses.text: When he had completed all his words in the hearing of the people, he entered Capernaum.
Now a certain centurion had a slave who was ill and about to die—one who was precious to him.
When he heard about Jesus, he sent some Jewish elders to him, asking him to come and save his slave's life.
When they came to Jesus, they pleaded with him earnestly, saying, "He is worthy for you to grant this,
for he loves our nation, and he himself built the synagogue for us."
So Jesus went with them. When he was not far from the house, the centurion sent friends to say to him: "Lord, do not trouble yourself, for I am not worthy for you to come under my roof.
That is why I did not even consider myself worthy to come to you. But speak the word, and let my servant be healed.
For I too am a man placed under authority, with soldiers under me. I say to this one, 'Go,' and he goes; and to another, 'Come,' and he comes; and to my slave, 'Do this,' and he does it."
When Jesus heard this, he marveled at him, and turning to the crowd following him, he said, "I tell you, not even in Israel have I found such faith."
And when those who had been sent returned to the house, they found the slave in good health.
Soon afterward, he traveled to a town called Nain, and his disciples and a large crowd were traveling with him.
As he drew near to the gate of the town, look—a dead man was being carried out, the only son of his mother, and she was a widow. A considerable crowd from the town was with her.
When the Lord saw her, he was moved with compassion for her and said to her, "Do not weep."
Then he came forward and touched the bier, and those carrying it stood still. He said, "Young man, I say to you: arise."
And the dead man sat up and began to speak, and Jesus gave him to his mother.
Awe seized everyone, and they glorified God, saying, "A great prophet has risen among us," and "God has visited his people."
And this report about him spread throughout all Judea and all the surrounding region.
John's disciples reported all these things to him. And summoning two of his disciples, John
sent them to the Lord, saying, "Are you the Coming One, or should we expect another?"
When the men came to him, they said, "John the Baptizer sent us to you, saying, 'Are you the Coming One, or should we expect another?'"
In that very hour, he healed many from diseases and afflictions and evil spirits, and to many who were blind he granted sight.

And he answered them, "Go and report to John what you have seen and heard: the blind see again, the lame walk, those with skin diseases are cleansed, the deaf hear, the dead are raised, the poor have good news proclaimed to them.
And blessed is the one who is not caused to stumble because of me."
When John's messengers had gone, Jesus began to speak to the crowds about John: "What did you go out into the wilderness to see? A reed being shaken by the wind?
Then what did you go out to see? A man dressed in soft garments? Look—those in splendid clothing who live in luxury are in royal palaces.
Then what did you go out to see? A prophet? Yes, I tell you, and more than a prophet.
This is the one about whom it is written: 'Look, I am sending my messenger before your face, who will prepare your way ahead of you.'
"I tell you, among those born of women, no one is greater than John. Yet the least in the kingdom of God is greater than he."
(And all the people who heard this—even the tax collectors—acknowledged God's righteousness, having been baptized with John's baptism.
But the Pharisees and the legal experts rejected God's purpose for themselves, not having been baptized by him.)
"To what, then, shall I compare the people of this generation? What are they like?
They are like children sitting in the marketplace and calling out to one another: 'We played the flute for you, and you did not dance; we sang a dirge, and you did not weep.'
For John the Baptizer came neither eating bread nor drinking wine, and you say, 'He has a demon.'
The Son of Man came eating and drinking, and you say, 'Look—a glutton and a drunkard, a friend of tax collectors and sinners!'
Yet wisdom is vindicated by all her children."
One of the Pharisees asked him to eat with him, and entering the Pharisee's house, he reclined at table.
And look—a woman from the city who was a sinner, learning that he was reclining at table in the Pharisee's house, brought an alabaster jar of perfumed oil.
Standing behind at his feet, weeping, she began to wet his feet with her tears, and she wiped them with the hair of her head, and she kept kissing his feet and anointing them with the oil.
When the Pharisee who had invited him saw this, he said to himself, "If this man were a prophet, he would know who and what kind of woman this is who is touching him—that she is a sinner."
Jesus answered him, "Simon, I have something to say to you." He said, "Teacher, speak."
"A certain moneylender had two debtors. One owed five hundred denarii, and the other fifty.
When they could not repay, he graciously forgave both. So which of them will love him more?"
Simon answered, "I suppose the one to whom he graciously forgave more." He said to him, "You have judged correctly."
Then turning toward the woman, he said to Simon, "Do you see this woman? I entered your house—you gave me no water for my feet, but she has wet my feet with her tears and wiped them with her hair.
You gave me no kiss, but from the moment I entered she has not stopped kissing my feet.
You did not anoint my head with oil, but she has anointed my feet with perfumed oil.
For this reason I tell you, her many sins have been forgiven—as her great love shows. But the one who is forgiven little loves little."
Then he said to her, "Your sins are forgiven."
Those reclining at table with him began to say among themselves, "Who is this, who even forgives sins?"
But he said to the woman, "Your faith has saved you. Go in peace."

chapters.notes:
**"Precious to him" (v. 2)**: Greek ἔντιμος means "held in honor," "highly valued"—stronger than simply "valued" or "dear," suggesting exceptional regard unusual for a slave relationship.

**"Save his slave's life" (v. 3)**: The Greek διασώσῃ is an intensified form of "save," meaning "bring safely through"—here carrying the sense of rescuing from death.

**"Moved with compassion" (v. 13)**: Greek ἐσπλαγχνίσθη derives from σπλάγχνα (viscera, intestines). This is a visceral, gut-level compassion—not mere pity but deep physical empathy.

**"Gave him to his mother" (v. 15)**: This phrase deliberately echoes 1 Kings 17:23 (LXX), where Elijah raises the widow of Zarephath's son and "gave him to his mother." Luke signals that Jesus is acting in the prophetic tradition—which the crowd immediately recognizes in v. 16.

**"The Coming One" (v. 19, 20)**: ὁ ἐρχόμενος was a recognized messianic title, referring to the expected deliverer. The definite article marks this as a specific figure.

**"Granted sight" (v. 21)**: The verb ἐχαρίσατο means "graciously gave as a gift"—emphasizing the healing as pure grace, not earned.

**"Acknowledged God's righteousness" (v. 29)**: Greek ἐδικαίωσαν τὸν θεόν—literally "justified God"—means they declared God to be in the right, vindicating his purposes through their response to John's baptism.

**"Rejected God's purpose for themselves" (v. 30)**: The phrase εἰς ἑαυτούς ("for/against themselves") indicates that their rejection of God's counsel harmed themselves.

**"Kept kissing" (v. 38, 45)**: The verb κατεφίλει uses an intensive prefix and imperfect tense, indicating continuous, fervent action—not a single kiss but repeated kissing.

**"As her great love shows" (v. 47)**: The Greek ὅτι here is notoriously difficult. The parable clearly teaches that forgiveness produces love (not that love earns forgiveness). The ὅτι clause best reads as evidential: her great love demonstrates that she has been forgiven much, not that her love caused the forgiveness. This translation makes this logic explicit.

**"Go in peace" (v. 50)**: Greek εἰς εἰρήνην (literally "into peace") reflects the Hebrew לְשָׁלוֹם—a blessing formula meaning to enter into a state of wholeness and wellbeing.

verses.text: And it happened in the time that followed that he was traveling through city after city and village after village, proclaiming and announcing the good news of the kingdom of God. The Twelve were with him,
along with certain women who had been healed from evil spirits and illnesses: Mary called Magdalene, from whom seven demons had gone out,
and Joanna the wife of Chuza, Herod's steward, and Susanna, and many others who were providing for them out of their own resources.
When a large crowd was gathering, with people coming to him from every city, he spoke through a parable:
"The sower went out to sow his seed. And as he sowed, some fell along the path and was trampled down, and the birds of the sky devoured it.
And other seed fell down on the rock, and after sprouting it withered because it had no moisture.
And other seed fell in the midst of the thorns, and the thorns grew up with it and choked it.
And other seed fell into the good soil, and after sprouting it produced fruit a hundredfold." Saying these things, he called out: "The one who has ears to hear—let him hear!"
His disciples began asking him what this parable meant.
He said, "To you it has been granted to know the mysteries of the kingdom of God, but to the rest it comes in parables, so that seeing they may not see, and hearing they may not understand.
"Now this is the parable: The seed is the word of God.
Those along the path are the ones who hear, but then the devil comes and takes away the word from their hearts, so that they may not believe and be saved.
Those on the rock are the ones who, when they hear, receive the word with joy—yet these have no root; they believe for a season, and in a season of testing they fall away.
As for what fell among the thorns, these are the ones who hear, but as they go along they are choked by the anxieties and wealth and pleasures of life, and they never bring fruit to maturity.
But as for what is in the good soil, these are the ones who hear the word and hold fast to it in a noble and good heart, and bear fruit through patient endurance.
"No one lights a lamp and covers it with a vessel or places it under a bed. Instead, he puts it on the lampstand, so that those who enter may see the light.
For there is nothing hidden that will not become visible, nor anything concealed that will not be known and come into the open.
Watch, then, how you hear. For whoever has, more will be given to him; and whoever does not have, even what he thinks he has will be taken from him."
Now his mother and his brothers came to him, but they were unable to reach him because of the crowd.
It was reported to him, "Your mother and your brothers are standing outside, wanting to see you."
But he answered them, "My mother and my brothers are these: those who hear the word of God and do it."
On one of those days, he got into a boat along with his disciples and said to them, "Let us cross over to the other side of the lake." And they set sail.
As they were sailing, he fell asleep. Then a windstorm descended upon the lake, and they were being swamped and were in danger.
They came and woke him, saying, "Master, Master, we are perishing!" Rising up, he rebuked the wind and the surging of the water—and they stopped, and there was calm.
He said to them, "Where is your faith?" Filled with awe and fear, they said to one another, "Who then is this, that he commands even the winds and the water, and they obey him?"
They sailed down to the region of the Gerasenes, which is opposite Galilee.
When he stepped out onto the land, a man from the city who had demons met him. For a long time he had not worn clothing, and he did not stay in a house but among the tombs.
When he saw Jesus, he cried out and fell before him, and said with a loud voice, "What do you want with me, Jesus, Son of the Most High God? I beg you, do not torment me!"—

for Jesus had been commanding the unclean spirit to come out of the man. For many times it had seized him, and though he was bound with chains and shackles and kept under guard, he would break the bonds and be driven by the demon into the desolate places.
Jesus asked him, "What is your name?" And he said, "Legion"—because many demons had entered him.
And they were begging him not to command them to go away into the abyss.
Now there was a large herd of pigs feeding there on the hillside, and the demons begged him to permit them to enter into those pigs. And he permitted them.
So the demons came out of the man and entered into the pigs, and the herd rushed down the steep bank into the lake and was drowned.
When the herdsmen saw what had happened, they fled and reported it in the city and in the countryside.
People came out to see what had happened, and they came to Jesus and found the man from whom the demons had gone out sitting at the feet of Jesus, clothed and in his right mind—and they were afraid.
Those who had seen it reported to them how the demon-possessed man had been saved.
Then the whole multitude from the surrounding region of the Gerasenes asked Jesus to depart from them, for they were seized with great fear. So he got into the boat and returned.
The man from whom the demons had gone out was begging to be with him, but Jesus sent him away, saying,
"Return to your home and tell all that God has done for you." And he went away, proclaiming throughout the whole city all that Jesus had done for him.
When Jesus returned, the crowd welcomed him, for they were all expecting him.
And behold, a man named Jairus came—he was a ruler of the synagogue—and falling at the feet of Jesus, he was begging him to come to his house,
because he had an only daughter, about twelve years old, and she was dying. As Jesus was going, the crowds were pressing in on him.
And a woman who had had a flow of blood for twelve years, and who had spent her whole livelihood on physicians but could not be healed by anyone,
came up behind him and touched the tassel of his garment, and immediately her flow of blood stopped.
Jesus said, "Who touched me?" When everyone was denying it, Peter said, "Master, the crowds are surrounding you and pressing against you."
But Jesus said, "Someone touched me, for I perceived power going out from me."

When the woman saw that she had not escaped notice, she came trembling and fell down before him, and in the presence of all the people she declared the reason she had touched him and how she had been healed immediately.
And he said to her, "Daughter, your faith has saved you. Go in peace."
While he was still speaking, someone came from the synagogue ruler's house, saying, "Your daughter has died; do not trouble the teacher any longer."
But Jesus, hearing this, answered him, "Do not be afraid; only believe, and she will be saved."
When he came to the house, he did not allow anyone to enter with him except Peter and John and James and the father and mother of the child.
Everyone was weeping and mourning for her, but he said, "Do not weep, for she has not died but is sleeping."
And they laughed at him, knowing that she had died.
But taking hold of her hand, he called out, "Child, arise!"
And her spirit returned, and she rose up immediately. And he ordered that she be given something to eat.
Her parents were beside themselves, but he commanded them to tell no one what had happened.

chapters.notes:
**"Providing for them" (v. 3)**: The Greek διηκόνουν means serving or ministering, and with ἐκ τῶν ὑπαρχόντων αὐταῖς ("out of their possessions") indicates these women were financially supporting Jesus's ministry—a significant detail Luke preserves about the material backing of the itinerant movement.

**"Tassel" (v. 44)**: The Greek κράσπεδον refers to the fringes (Hebrew: tzitzit) commanded in Numbers 15:38-39 and Deuteronomy 22:12. These tassels were worn as reminders of the commandments. The woman's touch is thus religiously significant—she reaches for a sacred element of his garment.

**"Noble and good heart" (v. 15)**: The phrase καρδίᾳ καλῇ καὶ ἀγαθῇ uses two Greek adjectives for good. The combination καλὸς κἀγαθός was a well-known Greek ideal of nobility and goodness. Luke may be deliberately using language resonant with Hellenistic moral vocabulary.

**"Bring fruit to maturity" (v. 14)**: The Greek τελεσφοροῦσιν (a hapax in the NT) specifically means to bring to completion or full development—stronger than simply "bear fruit." The word emphasizes the failure to reach full fruition.

**"In a season of testing" (v. 13)**: The word πειρασμός can mean temptation or testing/trial. "Testing" captures the broader semantic range—these are people whose faith does not survive difficult circumstances.

**"Abyss" (v. 31)**: The ἄβυσσος refers to the primordial deep and, in apocalyptic literature, the place where evil spirits are imprisoned (cf. Revelation 9:1, 20:1-3). The demons fear being sent to this place of confinement before the appointed time.

**"In his right mind" (v. 35)**: The Greek σωφρονοῦντα indicates sound-mindedness, self-control, rationality—the opposite of the chaotic, driven existence described earlier.

**"Saved" (vv. 36, 48, 50)**: The verb σῴζω means both to heal/make well and to save in the theological sense. Luke uses it throughout this chapter with layered meaning—physical restoration and spiritual deliverance interweave.

**"Master" (vv. 24, 45)**: The Greek Ἐπιστάτα is Luke's preferred term of address (used only in Luke in the NT), meaning something like "commander" or "chief"—a term of authority and respect.

verses.text: Having called together the twelve, he gave them power and authority over all demons and to heal diseases,
and he sent them out to proclaim the kingdom of God and to heal the sick.
And he said to them, "Take nothing for the journey—neither staff nor bag nor bread nor money—and do not have two tunics each.
Whatever house you enter, stay there and depart from there.
And wherever they do not welcome you, as you leave that town shake off the dust from your feet as a testimony against them."
So they set out and traveled through the villages, proclaiming the good news and healing everywhere.
Now Herod the tetrarch heard about all that was happening, and he was perplexed because it was being said by some that John had been raised from the dead,
by others that Elijah had appeared, and by still others that one of the ancient prophets had risen.
But Herod said, "John I myself beheaded—so who is this about whom I hear such things?" And he kept seeking to see him.
When the apostles returned, they recounted to him everything they had done. Taking them with him, he withdrew privately to a town called Bethsaida.
But the crowds found out and followed him. Welcoming them, he spoke to them about the kingdom of God and healed those who had need of healing.

Now the day began to decline. The twelve approached him and said, "Dismiss the crowd so they can go into the surrounding villages and countryside to find lodging and provisions, because we are here in a desolate place."
But he said to them, "You give them something to eat." They said, "We have no more than five loaves and two fish—unless we ourselves go and buy food for all these people."
For there were about five thousand men. He said to his disciples, "Have them recline in groups of about fifty each."
And they did so and had everyone recline.
Taking the five loaves and the two fish, he looked up to heaven, blessed them, broke them, and kept giving them to the disciples to set before the crowd.
And everyone ate and was satisfied, and what remained of the broken pieces was gathered up—twelve baskets.
Now it happened that while he was praying in a secluded place, his disciples were with him. And he asked them, "Who do the crowds say that I am?"
They answered, "John the Baptizer—but others say Elijah, and others that one of the ancient prophets has risen."
He said to them, "But you—who do you say that I am?" Peter answered, "The Christ of God."
But he warned them sternly and commanded them to tell this to no one,
saying, "The Son of Man must suffer many things and be rejected by the elders and chief priests and scribes, and be killed, and on the third day be raised."
And he said to all of them, "If anyone wants to come after me, let him deny himself and take up his cross daily, and follow me.
For whoever wants to save his life will lose it, but whoever loses his life for my sake—this one will save it.
For what does it profit a person to gain the whole world but lose or forfeit himself?
For whoever is ashamed of me and my words, the Son of Man will be ashamed of that one when he comes in his glory and the glory of the Father and of the holy angels.
But I tell you truly, there are some standing here who will certainly not taste death until they see the kingdom of God."
Now it happened about eight days after these words that he took Peter and John and James and went up the mountain to pray.
And while he was praying, the appearance of his face became different, and his clothing became white, flashing like lightning.
And look—two men were conversing with him, who were Moses and Elijah.
Appearing in glory, they were speaking about his exodus, which he was about to fulfill in Jerusalem.
Now Peter and those with him had been weighed down with sleep, but becoming fully awake, they saw his glory and the two men standing with him.

And as they were departing from him, Peter said to Jesus, "Master, it is good for us to be here. Let us make three shelters—one for you and one for Moses and one for Elijah"—not knowing what he was saying.
While he was saying this, a cloud formed and began to overshadow them. They became afraid as they entered the cloud.
And a voice came from the cloud, saying, "This is my Son, the Chosen One. Listen to him!"
When the voice had spoken, Jesus was found alone. And they kept silent and told no one in those days anything of what they had seen.
Now on the following day, when they had come down from the mountain, a large crowd met him.
And suddenly a man from the crowd cried out, "Teacher, I beg you to look upon my son, because he is my only child!
A spirit seizes him, and suddenly he screams, and it convulses him with foaming, and it departs from him only with difficulty, crushing him.
I begged your disciples to cast it out, but they were not able."
Jesus answered, "O faithless and twisted generation! How long shall I be with you and put up with you? Bring your son here."
While the boy was still approaching, the demon threw him down and convulsed him violently. But Jesus rebuked the unclean spirit and healed the boy and gave him back to his father.
And everyone was astounded at the majesty of God. While all were marveling at everything he was doing, he said to his disciples,
"Let these words sink into your ears: the Son of Man is about to be handed over into human hands."
But they did not understand this saying; it was concealed from them so that they would not grasp it, and they were afraid to ask him about it.
Now an argument arose among them about which of them might be greatest.
But Jesus, knowing the reasoning of their hearts, took hold of a child and set the child beside himself,
and said to them, "Whoever welcomes this child in my name welcomes me, and whoever welcomes me welcomes the one who sent me. For the one who is least among all of you—this one is great."
John responded, "Master, we saw someone casting out demons in your name, and we tried to stop him because he does not follow with us."
But Jesus said to him, "Do not stop him. For whoever is not against you is for you."
Now when the days were drawing near for his being taken up, he set his face to go to Jerusalem.
And he sent messengers ahead of him. They went and entered a village of the Samaritans to prepare for him,
but they did not welcome him, because his face was set toward Jerusalem.
When his disciples James and John saw this, they said, "Lord, do you want us to call fire down from heaven to consume them?"
But turning, he rebuked them.
And they went on to another village.
As they were traveling along the road, someone said to him, "I will follow you wherever you go."
And Jesus said to him, "Foxes have dens, and birds of the sky have nests, but the Son of Man has no place to lay his head."
To another he said, "Follow me." But he said, "Lord, permit me first to go and bury my father."
But he said to him, "Let the dead bury their own dead. But you—go and proclaim the kingdom of God."
Another also said, "I will follow you, Lord, but first permit me to say farewell to those in my household."
But Jesus said, "No one who puts his hand to the plow and looks back is fit for the kingdom of God."

chapters.notes:
**"Exodus" (v. 31)**: The Greek ἔξοδον deliberately evokes Israel's departure from Egypt. Luke's choice is theologically loaded—Jesus's death in Jerusalem is being framed as a new exodus, a liberation. "Departure" (common in translations) loses this resonance entirely.

**"The Chosen One" (v. 35)**: Luke uniquely has ὁ ἐκλελεγμένος where Matthew and Mark have "beloved." This echoes Isaiah 42:1 (the Servant Song) and presents Jesus specifically as God's elect one. The SBLGNT follows this reading.

**"Let these words sink into your ears" (v. 44)**: The Greek Θέσθε...εἰς τὰ ὦτα ὑμῶν is a Semitic idiom meaning "listen carefully and remember." A literal "put into your ears" sounds odd in English; "sink into" captures the sense of penetration and retention.

**"Twisted" (v. 41)**: διεστραμμένη echoes Deuteronomy 32:5 (LXX), where Moses calls Israel a "crooked and twisted generation." Jesus's lament deliberately recalls Moses's frustration with Israel. "Perverse" is accurate but has acquired narrower connotations in modern English.

**"Set his face" (v. 51, 53)**: τὸ πρόσωπον ἐστήρισεν is a Semitic idiom expressing firm resolve (cf. Isaiah 50:7, Ezekiel 21:2). The language appears twice, emphasizing Jesus's determined orientation toward Jerusalem and his fate there.

**"Being taken up" (v. 51)**: ἀναλήμψεως refers to Jesus's ascension, but Luke places it here proleptically—the entire journey to Jerusalem is framed by its ultimate endpoint. The term encompasses his death, resurrection, and ascension as one movement.

**"Master" (v. 33, 49)**: Ἐπιστάτα is Luke's distinctive term for Jesus (used only in Luke), meaning something like "commander" or "overseer." It's how the disciples address Jesus and carries more authority than simply "teacher."

**"Crush" (v. 39)**: συντρῖβον describes the spirit's effect—literally "shattering" or "crushing" the boy. This conveys the violence and destruction more forcefully than softer alternatives like "injure."

verses.text: After this, the Lord appointed seventy-two others and sent them ahead of him in pairs to every town and place where he himself was about to go.
He said to them: "The harvest is plentiful, but the workers are few. Plead then with the master of the harvest to thrust workers out into his harvest.
Go! Look—I am sending you out like lambs into the midst of wolves.
Carry no money bag, no traveler's sack, no sandals, and greet no one along the road.
Whatever house you enter, first say, 'Peace to this house.'
And if a son of peace is there, your peace will rest upon him. But if not, it will return to you.
Remain in that same house, eating and drinking what they provide, for the worker deserves his wages. Do not move from house to house.
And whenever you enter a town and they welcome you, eat what is set before you,
heal the sick who are there, and say to them, 'The kingdom of God has come near to you.'
But whenever you enter a town and they do not welcome you, go out into its streets and say,
'Even the dust of your town that clings to our feet we wipe off against you. Yet know this: the kingdom of God has come near.'
I tell you, on that day it will be more bearable for Sodom than for that town.
"Woe to you, Chorazin! Woe to you, Bethsaida! For if the mighty works done among you had been done in Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long ago, sitting in sackcloth and ashes.
But it will be more bearable for Tyre and Sidon at the judgment than for you.
And you, Capernaum—will you be exalted to heaven? You will be brought down to Hades.
"The one who listens to you listens to me, and the one who rejects you rejects me. And the one who rejects me rejects the one who sent me."
The seventy-two returned with joy, saying, "Lord, even the demons submit to us in your name!"
He said to them, "I was watching Satan fall from heaven like lightning.
Look—I have given you authority to trample on snakes and scorpions, and over all the power of the enemy, and nothing will ever harm you.
Nevertheless, do not rejoice in this—that the spirits submit to you. Rather, rejoice that your names have been inscribed in the heavens."

In that very hour he exulted in the Holy Spirit and said, "I praise you, Father, Lord of heaven and earth, because you have hidden these things from the wise and the learned and revealed them to infants. Yes, Father, for this was your good pleasure.
All things have been entrusted to me by my Father. And no one knows who the Son is except the Father, or who the Father is except the Son—and anyone to whom the Son chooses to reveal him."
Then turning to the disciples privately, he said, "Blessed are the eyes that see what you see.
For I tell you that many prophets and kings longed to see what you see and did not see it, and to hear what you hear and did not hear it."
And look—a certain expert in the law stood up to test him, saying, "Teacher, what must I do to inherit eternal life?"
He said to him, "What is written in the law? How do you read it?"
He answered, "You shall love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your strength and with all your mind, and your neighbor as yourself."
He said to him, "You have answered correctly. Do this and you will live."
But wanting to justify himself, he said to Jesus, "And who is my neighbor?"
Jesus took up the matter and said: "A man was going down from Jerusalem to Jericho, and he fell among bandits. They stripped him, beat him, and went off, leaving him half-dead.
Now by chance a priest was going down that road, and when he saw him, he passed by on the opposite side.
Likewise a Levite, when he came to the place and saw him, passed by on the opposite side.
But a Samaritan who was traveling came upon him, and when he saw him, he was moved with compassion.
He went to him and bound up his wounds, pouring on oil and wine. Then he set him on his own animal, brought him to an inn, and cared for him.
On the next day, he took out two denarii and gave them to the innkeeper and said, 'Take care of him, and whatever more you spend, I will repay you when I return.'
"Which of these three, do you think, proved to be a neighbor to the man who fell among the bandits?"
He said, "The one who showed him mercy." Jesus said to him, "Go and do likewise."
As they were traveling, he entered a certain village, and a woman named Martha welcomed him into her home.
She had a sister called Mary, who sat at the Lord's feet and was listening to his word.
But Martha was pulled in all directions by much serving. She came up to him and said, "Lord, do you not care that my sister has left me to serve alone? Tell her then to help me."
But the Lord answered her, "Martha, Martha, you are anxious and agitated about many things,
but few things are needed—or only one. For Mary has chosen the good portion, which will not be taken from her."

chapters.notes:
**"Thrust workers out" (v. 2)**: The verb ἐκβάλῃ is forceful—the same word used for casting out demons. "Send" is too weak. The harvest is urgent; workers must be propelled into it.

**"Son of peace" (v. 6)**: A Semitic idiom (בֶּן־שָׁלוֹם) meaning one characterized by or receptive to peace. Retaining this rather than smoothing it to "peaceful person" preserves the original idiom that would have been transparent to the audience.

**"Greet no one along the road" (v. 4)**: Not rudeness, but urgency. Ancient Near Eastern greetings involved extended formalities; the mission allows no delay.

**"I was watching" (v. 18)**: The imperfect ἐθεώρουν suggests ongoing vision—"I was beholding"—not a single past event. The timing is debated: cosmic prehistory, during the mission, or prophetic certainty of what their work inaugurates.

**"Exulted" (v. 21)**: ἠγαλλιάσατο is stronger than "rejoiced"—it's intense, expressive joy.

**"Infants" (v. 21)**: νηπίοις literally means infants/small children. The contrast with "wise and learned" (σοφῶν καὶ συνετῶν) is deliberately stark—divine revelation comes to the unsophisticated.

**"Fell among bandits" (v. 30)**: λῃσταί are violent robbers or bandits, not petty thieves (κλέπται). The Jericho road was notoriously dangerous.

**"Was moved with compassion" (v. 33)**: ἐσπλαγχνίσθη derives from σπλάγχνα (internal organs)—a visceral, gut-level response, not merely intellectual sympathy.

**"Pulled in all directions" (v. 40)**: περιεσπᾶτο means "dragged about"—Martha is being torn apart by her tasks. "Distracted" captures this, but "pulled in all directions" shows the intensity.
