**"Few things are needed—or only one" (v. 42)**: There is textual variation here. The reading followed suggests practical simplicity (few dishes needed) resolving into spiritual singularity (one thing needed). The ambiguity may be intentional.

verses.text: And it happened that while he was in a certain place praying, when he finished, one of his disciples said to him, "Lord, teach us to pray, just as John also taught his disciples."
He said to them, "When you pray, say: Father, let your name be treated as holy; let your kingdom come.
Give us each day our bread for the coming day.
And forgive us our sins, for we ourselves also forgive everyone indebted to us. And do not bring us into the time of testing."
And he said to them, "Suppose one of you has a friend, and you go to him at midnight and say to him, 'Friend, lend me three loaves,
because a friend of mine has arrived from traveling and I have nothing to set before him.'
And suppose he answers from inside, 'Don't bother me! The door has already been bolted, and my children are with me in bed. I cannot get up and give you anything.'
I tell you, even if he will not get up and give him anything because he is his friend, yet because of the man's shameless persistence he will get up and give him whatever he needs.
"And I tell you: Keep asking, and it will be given to you. Keep seeking, and you will find. Keep knocking, and it will be opened to you.
For everyone who asks receives, and the one who seeks finds, and to the one who knocks it will be opened.
"What father among you, if his son asks for a fish, will give him a snake instead?
Or if he asks for an egg, will give him a scorpion?
If you then, being wicked, know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more will the Father from heaven give the Holy Spirit to those who ask him!"
Now he was casting out a demon that caused muteness. When the demon had gone out, the mute man spoke, and the crowds were amazed.
But some of them said, "He casts out demons by Beelzebul, the ruler of the demons."
Others, testing him, kept demanding a sign from heaven.
But he, knowing their thoughts, said to them, "Every kingdom divided against itself is laid waste, and house falls against house.
If Satan also is divided against himself, how will his kingdom stand? For you say I cast out demons by Beelzebul.
But if I cast out demons by Beelzebul, by whom do your sons cast them out? Therefore they will be your judges.
But if I cast out demons by the finger of God, then the kingdom of God has arrived upon you.
"When the strong man, fully armed, guards his own estate, his possessions are secure.
But when one stronger than he attacks and overpowers him, he takes away the full armor in which he trusted, and distributes his plunder.
"Whoever is not with me is against me, and whoever does not gather with me scatters.
"When the unclean spirit goes out of a person, it passes through waterless regions seeking rest, and finding none, it says, 'I will return to my house from which I came.'
And when it arrives, it finds the house swept and put in order.
Then it goes and brings along seven other spirits more wicked than itself, and they enter and settle there, and the final condition of that person becomes worse than the first."
As he was saying these things, a woman in the crowd raised her voice and said to him, "Blessed is the womb that carried you and the breasts that nursed you!"
But he said, "Blessed rather are those who hear the word of God and guard it."
As the crowds were increasing, he began to say, "This generation is a wicked generation. It seeks a sign, and no sign will be given to it except the sign of Jonah.
For just as Jonah became a sign to the Ninevites, so also will the Son of Man be to this generation.

The Queen of the South will rise at the judgment with the men of this generation and will condemn them, because she came from the ends of the earth to hear the wisdom of Solomon—and look, something greater than Solomon is here.
The men of Nineveh will rise up at the judgment with this generation and will condemn it, because they repented at the proclamation of Jonah—and look, something greater than Jonah is here.
"No one lights a lamp and puts it in a cellar or under a basket, but on the lampstand, so that those who enter may see the light.
The lamp of the body is your eye. When your eye is sound, your whole body also is full of light. But when it is diseased, your body also is dark.
Watch out, then, that the light in you is not darkness.
If therefore your whole body is full of light, with no part dark, it will be entirely radiant, as when the lamp illuminates you with its flash."
While he was speaking, a Pharisee asked him to dine with him. So he went in and reclined at table.
The Pharisee, seeing this, was astonished that he did not first perform the ritual washing before the meal.
But the Lord said to him, "Now you Pharisees clean the outside of the cup and the dish, but inside you are full of greed and wickedness.
Fools! Did not the one who made the outside also make the inside?
But give what is within as charity, and look—everything becomes clean for you.
"But woe to you Pharisees! For you tithe mint and rue and every garden herb, yet you neglect justice and the love of God. These things you ought to have done without neglecting the others.
Woe to you Pharisees! For you love the seat of honor in the synagogues and the greetings in the marketplaces.
Woe to you! For you are like unmarked graves, and people walk over them without knowing it."
One of the legal experts answered him, "Teacher, when you say these things, you insult us too."
And he said, "Woe to you legal experts as well! For you load people with burdens hard to carry, yet you yourselves do not touch the burdens with even one of your fingers.
Woe to you! For you build the tombs of the prophets, but your fathers killed them.
So you are witnesses and approve of the deeds of your fathers: they killed them, and you build their tombs.
"For this reason also the Wisdom of God said, 'I will send them prophets and apostles, and some of them they will kill and persecute,'
so that the blood of all the prophets shed since the foundation of the world may be charged against this generation—
from the blood of Abel to the blood of Zechariah, who perished between the altar and the sanctuary. Yes, I tell you, it will be charged against this generation.
"Woe to you legal experts! For you have taken away the key of knowledge. You yourselves did not enter, and those who were entering you hindered."
When he went out from there, the scribes and the Pharisees began to be fiercely hostile and to interrogate him about many things,
lying in wait for him to catch something from his mouth.

chapters.notes:
**"Bread for the coming day" (v. 3)**: The word ἐπιούσιον appears almost nowhere else in Greek literature and its meaning is debated. Options include "daily," "necessary for existence," or "for the coming day." Given the phrase τὸ καθ' ἡμέραν ("each day") that follows in Luke, I've rendered it to emphasize provision for each day's need rather than stockpiling—consistent with the manna tradition where Israel gathered only what was needed for each day.

**"Time of testing" (v. 4)**: The Greek πειρασμόν means "test" or "trial" more than "temptation" in the modern sense of enticement to sin. The petition asks God not to bring us into a situation of severe testing or trial.

**"Shameless persistence" (v. 8)**: The word ἀναίδεια literally means "shamelessness." In an honor-shame culture, this could refer either to the asker's bold persistence or to the sleeper's desire to avoid the shame of refusing. I've followed the traditional reading (the asker's persistence), though the alternative interpretation has scholarly support.

**"Keep asking... keep seeking... keep knocking" (v. 9)**: The Greek verbs are present imperatives, indicating continuous or repeated action, not one-time requests.

**"Finger of God" (v. 20)**: This phrase echoes Exodus 8:19, where Pharaoh's magicians acknowledge God's power in the plagues. Where Matthew has "Spirit of God," Luke preserves this Exodus allusion.

**"Has arrived" (v. 20)**: The verb ἔφθασεν indicates actual arrival, not merely approach. The kingdom has genuinely come upon them in Jesus's exorcisms.

**"Sound... diseased" (v. 34)**: The Greek ἁπλοῦς can mean "simple," "single," "healthy," or "generous" (a "good eye" in Semitic idiom meant generosity). Similarly, πονηρός can mean "evil" or refer to a diseased/bad eye. In this light/darkness context, I've used "sound" and "diseased" to capture both the physical and moral dimensions.

**"Ritual washing" (v. 38)**: The verb ἐβαπτίσθη here refers to Jewish ritual immersion or washing before meals, not Christian baptism.

**"Give what is within as charity" (v. 41)**: This verse is notoriously difficult. The Greek τὰ ἐνόντα ("the things inside") may mean "give from the heart" or "give what you have" as alms—the point being that inner transformation, expressed in generosity, is what truly cleanses.

**"Legal experts" (vv. 45-52)**: The νομικοί were experts in the Mosaic law, a category overlapping with but distinct from the scribes and Pharisees. "Lawyers" is the traditional rendering but suggests modern attorneys; "legal experts" clarifies their specialty in Torah interpretation.

**"The Wisdom of God said" (v. 49)**: This introduces a quotation whose source is unknown—possibly personified Wisdom speaking, or a reference to a lost text, or Jesus speaking as divine Wisdom.

verses.text: Meanwhile, when the crowd had gathered in such vast numbers—tens of thousands—that they were trampling one another, he began to speak to his disciples first: "Guard yourselves against the leaven of the Pharisees, which is play-acting.
Nothing that has been covered up will remain hidden—it will be revealed. And nothing secret will remain unknown—it will be made known.
Therefore, whatever you have said in the darkness will be heard in the light, and what you have whispered in the innermost rooms will be proclaimed from the rooftops.
"I say to you, my friends: do not fear those who kill the body and after that can do nothing more.
But I will show you whom to fear: fear the one who, after killing, has authority to cast into Gehenna. Yes, I tell you, fear this one!
Are not five sparrows sold for two small coins? Yet not one of them is forgotten before God.
But even the hairs of your head have all been counted. Do not be afraid—you are worth more than many sparrows.
"I tell you, everyone who acknowledges me before others, the Son of Man will also acknowledge before the angels of God.
But whoever denies me before others will be denied before the angels of God.
And everyone who speaks a word against the Son of Man will be forgiven, but the one who blasphemes against the Holy Spirit will not be forgiven.
"When they bring you before synagogues and rulers and authorities, do not be anxious about how you will defend yourselves or what you will say,
for the Holy Spirit will teach you in that very hour what must be said."
Someone from the crowd said to him, "Teacher, tell my brother to divide the inheritance with me."
But he said to him, "Friend, who appointed me a judge or arbitrator over you?"
Then he said to them, "Watch out! Guard yourselves against every kind of greed, for a person's life does not consist in the abundance of possessions."
And he told them a parable: "The land of a certain rich man produced an abundant harvest.
He began reasoning to himself, 'What should I do? I have no place to store my crops.'
Then he said, 'This is what I will do: I will tear down my barns and build larger ones, and there I will store all my grain and goods.
And I will say to my soul: Soul, you have many good things stored up for many years. Rest, eat, drink, celebrate!'
But God said to him, 'Fool! This very night your soul is being demanded from you. And the things you have prepared—whose will they be?'
So it is with the one who stores up treasure for himself but is not rich toward God."
Then he said to his disciples, "For this reason I tell you: do not be anxious about your life—what you will eat—or about your body—what you will wear.
For life is more than food, and the body more than clothing.
Consider the ravens: they do not sow or reap; they have no storeroom or barn, yet God feeds them. How much more valuable you are than the birds!
And which of you by being anxious can add a single moment to your lifespan?
If then you cannot do even this smallest thing, why are you anxious about the rest?
"Consider the lilies, how they grow: they do not labor or spin. Yet I tell you, not even Solomon in all his glory was clothed like one of these.
But if God so clothes the grass in the field, which exists today and tomorrow is thrown into the oven, how much more will he clothe you, you of little faith!
And do not keep seeking what you will eat or what you will drink, and do not be unsettled.
For all the nations of the world chase after these things, but your Father knows you need them.
Instead, seek his kingdom, and these things will be added to you.
"Do not be afraid, little flock, for your Father has delighted to give you the kingdom.
Sell your possessions and give to the poor. Make for yourselves purses that do not wear out—an inexhaustible treasure in the heavens, where no thief comes near and no moth destroys.
For where your treasure is, there your heart will be also.
"Let your waists be girded and your lamps burning,
and be like people waiting for their master to return from the wedding feast, so that when he comes and knocks, they may open the door for him immediately.
Blessed are those servants whom the master finds watchful when he arrives. Truly I tell you, he will gird himself, have them recline at table, and come and serve them.
And if he comes in the second watch, or even in the third, and finds them ready—blessed are they!
"But know this: if the master of the house had known at what hour the thief was coming, he would not have let his house be broken into.
You also must be ready, because the Son of Man is coming at an hour you do not expect."
Peter said, "Lord, are you telling this parable for us, or for everyone?"
The Lord said, "Who then is the faithful and prudent steward whom the master will put in charge of his household servants to give them their food ration at the proper time?
Blessed is that servant whom his master finds doing so when he arrives.
Truly I tell you, he will put him in charge of all his possessions.
But if that servant says in his heart, 'My master is taking a long time to come,' and begins to beat the male and female servants, and to eat and drink and get drunk,
the master of that servant will come on a day he does not expect, at an hour he does not know, and will cut him in pieces and assign him a place with the unfaithful.
"That servant who knew his master's will but did not prepare or act according to his will—he will be beaten with many blows.

But the one who did not know, yet did things deserving punishment, will be beaten with few blows. From everyone who has been given much, much will be required; and from the one who has been entrusted with much, even more will be demanded.
"I came to cast fire upon the earth, and how I wish it were already ablaze!
I have a baptism to undergo, and how distressed I am until it is accomplished!
Do you think I came to bring peace to the earth? No, I tell you, but rather division.
For from now on, five in one household will be divided: three against two and two against three.
They will be divided—father against son and son against father, mother against daughter and daughter against mother, mother-in-law against daughter-in-law and daughter-in-law against mother-in-law."
He also said to the crowds, "When you see a cloud rising in the west, you say at once, 'A rainstorm is coming'—and so it does.
And when you see the south wind blowing, you say, 'It will be scorching hot'—and it is.
Performers! You know how to interpret the appearance of the earth and sky, but how is it you do not know how to interpret this present time?
And why do you not judge for yourselves what is right?

"As you are going with your adversary to appear before a magistrate, make every effort to settle with him on the way, or he may drag you before the judge, and the judge hand you over to the officer, and the officer throw you into prison.
I tell you, you will never get out until you have paid the very last penny."

chapters.notes:
**"Play-acting" (v. 1) / "Performers" (v. 56)**: The Greek ὑπόκρισις and ὑποκριταί derive from theatrical vocabulary—stage acting and actors playing roles. The Pharisees' problem is not that they believe one thing and do another (the modern sense of "hypocrite"), but that their piety is performance. "Play-acting" and "performers" recover this original meaning.

**"Innermost rooms" (v. 3)**: Greek ταμεῖον refers to the most private domestic space—a storeroom or inner chamber, not simply any "room." The contrast is between maximum privacy and maximum publicity (rooftops were public gathering places).

**"Gehenna" (v. 5)**: I retained the transliteration rather than using "hell," which carries too much later theological baggage. Gehenna (גֵּי הִנֹּם, Valley of Hinnom) was a specific place associated with divine judgment.

**"Two small coins" (v. 6)**: Greek ἀσσαρίων δύο—two assaria, Roman copper coins worth about 1/16 of a denarius each. "Small coins" conveys the insignificant monetary value without the distraction of unfamiliar currency terms.

**"Lifespan" (v. 25)**: Greek ἡλικία can mean either physical stature or lifespan. The context of verse 26 ("this smallest thing") suggests lifespan—a πῆχυς (cubit, about 18 inches) would not be a "small" addition to one's height, but metaphorically it makes sense as a minimal addition to life's duration.

**"Being demanded" (v. 20)**: The Greek ἀπαιτοῦσιν is third person plural ("they are demanding"), possibly a circumlocution for divine action or referring to angelic beings who collect souls. The passive construction preserves this ambiguity.

**"Cut him in pieces" (v. 46)**: Greek διχοτομήσει literally means "to cut in two." This is shockingly severe language; some argue it's hyperbolic or metaphorical, but I've translated it directly.

**"Unsettled" (v. 29)**: Greek μετεωρίζεσθε means to be raised up or suspended, hence agitated or anxious—hanging in worried suspense. "Unsettled" captures this better than a simple repetition of "worry."

**"Girded waists" (v. 35)**: This imagery alludes to Exodus 12:11, where Israelites ate the Passover with loins girded, ready for immediate departure. First-century readers would catch this Passover resonance.

**"This present time" (v. 56)**: Greek καιρός often means a decisive or opportune moment, not merely chronological time (χρόνος). Jesus is speaking about the critical nature of the current era, not just the season.

verses.text: Now some people were present at that very moment who reported to him about the Galileans whose blood Pilate had mixed with their sacrifices.
And responding, he said to them: "Do you think that these Galileans were sinners beyond all the other Galileans, because they suffered these things?
No, I tell you, but unless you all repent, you will perish in the same way.
Or those eighteen on whom the tower in Siloam fell and killed them—do you think they were more guilty than all the other people living in Jerusalem?
No, I tell you, but unless you all repent, you will perish just the same."
And he told this parable: "A man had a fig tree planted in his vineyard, and he came looking for fruit on it but found none.
So he said to the vineyard keeper: 'Look, for three years now I have been coming to look for fruit on this fig tree and I find none. Cut it down! Why should it even be wasting the soil?'
But he answered and said to him: 'Master, leave it alone this year also, until I dig around it and put manure on it.
And if it produces fruit next year—good. But if not, you can cut it down.'"
Now he was teaching in one of the synagogues on the Sabbath.
And there was a woman who had had a spirit of infirmity for eighteen years; she was bent over double and completely unable to straighten up.
When Jesus saw her, he called her over and said to her: "Woman, you have been set free from your infirmity."
And he laid his hands on her, and immediately she was straightened up, and she began glorifying God.

But the synagogue leader responded with indignation because Jesus had healed on the Sabbath, and said to the crowd: "There are six days on which work ought to be done. Come on those days to be healed, then, and not on the Sabbath day."
But the Lord answered him and said: "Pretenders! Does not each of you on the Sabbath untie his ox or his donkey from the feeding trough and lead it away to give it water?
And this woman, a daughter of Abraham, whom Satan bound—look!—for eighteen years, should she not have been untied from this bondage on the Sabbath day?"
And as he said these things, all his opponents were put to shame, while the whole crowd was rejoicing at all the glorious things being done by him.
So he said: "What is the kingdom of God like, and to what shall I compare it?
It is like a mustard seed that a man took and threw into his garden, and it grew and became a tree, and the birds of the sky made nests in its branches."
And again he said: "To what shall I compare the kingdom of God?
It is like leaven that a woman took and hid in three measures of flour until the whole batch was leavened."
And he was traveling through town by town and village by village, teaching and making his way toward Jerusalem.
Someone said to him: "Lord, are those being saved few?" And he said to them:
"Struggle to enter through the narrow door, because many, I tell you, will seek to enter and will not have the strength—

once the master of the house rises and shuts the door. Then you will begin to stand outside and knock on the door, saying: 'Lord, open to us!' And he will answer and say to you: 'I do not know where you are from.'
Then you will begin to say: 'We ate and drank in your presence, and you taught in our streets!'
And he will speak and say to you: 'I do not know where you are from. Get away from me, all you workers of injustice!'
There will be weeping and gnashing of teeth when you see Abraham and Isaac and Jacob and all the prophets in the kingdom of God, but yourselves thrown outside.
And people will come from east and west and from north and south and recline at the banquet in the kingdom of God.
And look: some who are last will be first, and some who are first will be last."
At that very hour some Pharisees came up and said to him: "Get out and go away from here, because Herod wants to kill you."
And he said to them: "Go tell that fox: 'Look, I am casting out demons and accomplishing healings today and tomorrow, and on the third day I reach my goal.'
But I must travel on today and tomorrow and the next day, because it is impossible for a prophet to perish outside Jerusalem."

"Jerusalem, Jerusalem—the one killing the prophets and stoning those sent to her! How often I have longed to gather your children together, the way a hen gathers her brood under her wings, but you were not willing!
Look, your house is abandoned to you. And I tell you, you will certainly not see me until the time comes when you say: 'Blessed is the one who comes in the name of the Lord.'"

chapters.notes:
**"More guilty" (v. 4)**: The Greek ὀφειλέται literally means "debtors"—those who owe something. In Jewish thought, sin creates a debt to God. "Guilty" captures this moral sense in English without requiring explanation of the debt metaphor.

**"Wasting the soil" (v. 7)**: καταργεῖ means to render ineffective or useless. The fig tree is not just taking up space but actively depleting resources that could benefit productive plants.

**"Pretenders" (v. 15)**: The Greek ὑποκριταί derives from theatrical performance—those who play a role on stage. "Hypocrites" in modern English has narrowed to mean believing one thing and doing another. Jesus's point is sharper: these are people performing religiosity while missing its heart. "Pretenders" captures the theatrical sense while remaining natural.

**"Untied... bondage" (v. 16)**: The Greek λυθῆναι (to be untied) and δεσμοῦ (bondage) deliberately echo the λύει (untie) of verse 15. Jesus creates a wordplay: you untie animals on the Sabbath, but object to this woman being untied from Satan's bondage? The translation preserves this connection.

**"Struggle" (v. 24)**: Ἀγωνίζεσθε is agonistic language—from the arena and athletic competition. It implies intense exertion and combat, not merely polite effort. "Struggle" captures this intensity better than "strive."

**"Recline at the banquet" (v. 29)**: ἀνακλιθήσονται means to recline at a meal, the posture for formal banqueting. The kingdom imagery here is of a great feast; "recline" preserves this cultural detail.

**"I reach my goal" (v. 32)**: τελειοῦμαι can mean "I am completed/perfected/finished." There is deliberate ambiguity—Jesus speaks of completing his work but also hints at his death (reaching his τέλος, his end/purpose). "I reach my goal" preserves this ambiguity better than "I am perfected" or "I finish."

**"Your house is abandoned to you" (v. 35)**: ἀφίεται means "is left" or "abandoned." "House" (οἶκος) likely refers to the Temple, though it can also mean household or dynasty. The passive voice is ominous—left by whom? The implication is divine abandonment.

verses.text: It happened that when he went into the house of one of the leaders of the Pharisees on the Sabbath to share a meal, they were watching him closely.
And right there in front of him was a man afflicted with dropsy.
Jesus responded by saying to the legal experts and Pharisees, "Is it lawful to heal on the Sabbath, or not?"
But they kept silent. So he took hold of the man, healed him, and sent him away.
Then he said to them, "Which of you, if your son or your ox falls into a well, will not immediately pull him out on the Sabbath day?"
And they could not answer this.
He then told an illustration to those who had been invited, having noticed how they were choosing the places of honor for themselves. He said to them:
"When you are invited by someone to a wedding banquet, do not recline in the place of honor, in case someone more distinguished than you has been invited by him,
and the one who invited both you and him will come and say to you, 'Give your place to this person.' Then you will begin, in shame, to take the lowest place.

Instead, when you are invited, go and recline in the lowest place, so that when your host comes he will say to you, 'Friend, move up higher.' Then you will have honor in the presence of all who are at the table with you.
For everyone who exalts himself will be humbled, and the one who humbles himself will be exalted."

He also said to the one who had invited him, "When you give a midday meal or a dinner, do not invite your friends or your brothers or your relatives or wealthy neighbors—otherwise they might invite you back, and that would be your repayment.
Instead, when you give a banquet, invite the destitute, the maimed, the lame, the blind.
And you will be blessed, because they have no way to repay you. For you will be repaid at the resurrection of the righteous."
When one of those at the table heard these things, he said to him, "Blessed is the one who will eat bread in the kingdom of God!"
But Jesus said to him, "A certain man was preparing a great dinner and invited many guests.
At the hour of the dinner, he sent his servant to tell those who had been invited, 'Come, for everything is now ready.'
But one and all, they began to make excuses. The first said to him, 'I have bought a field and I must go out to see it. Please consider me excused.'
Another said, 'I have bought five yoke of oxen and I am going to try them out. Please consider me excused.'
And another said, 'I have just married a wife, and for this reason I cannot come.'

The servant returned and reported all this to his master. Then the master of the house became angry and said to his servant, 'Go out quickly into the main streets and alleyways of the city, and bring in the destitute and the maimed and the blind and the lame.'
The servant said, 'Master, what you ordered has been done, and there is still room.'
The master said to the servant, 'Go out to the roads and along the hedgerows and compel them to come in, so that my house may be filled.
For I tell you, not one of those men who were invited will taste my dinner.'"
Now large crowds were traveling with him, and he turned and said to them:
"If anyone comes to me and does not hate his father and mother and wife and children and brothers and sisters—yes, even his own life—he cannot be my disciple.
Whoever does not carry his own cross and come after me cannot be my disciple.
"For which of you, wanting to build a tower, does not first sit down and calculate the cost—whether he has enough to complete it?
Otherwise, when he has laid the foundation but is unable to finish, everyone watching will begin to ridicule him,
saying, 'This man started to build and was not able to finish.'
"Or what king, going out to engage another king in battle, does not first sit down and deliberate whether he is able with ten thousand to confront the one coming against him with twenty thousand?
And if not, while the other is still far away, he sends an embassy and asks for terms of peace.
In the same way then, any of you who does not renounce all his possessions cannot be my disciple.
"Salt is good, but if even the salt loses its saltiness, with what will it be made salty again?
It is fit neither for the soil nor for the manure pile—they throw it out. Let the one who has ears to hear, hear."

chapters.notes:
**"Share a meal" (v. 1)**: The Greek φαγεῖν ἄρτον ("eat bread") is a Semitic idiom meaning to share a meal together, not specifically to eat bread.

**"Watching him closely" (v. 1)**: The verb παρατηρούμενοι suggests scrutinizing observation with suspicious or hostile intent, not neutral watching.

**"Dropsy" (v. 2)**: ὑδρωπικός refers to edema—abnormal fluid retention causing swelling. The term "dropsy" is retained as it accurately names this condition in period medical terminology.

**"Legal experts" (v. 3)**: νομικούς refers specifically to those professionally trained in Torah interpretation, distinct from Pharisees as a religious-political movement.

**"Places of honor" (v. 7)**: πρωτοκλισίας literally means "first reclining places"—at formal meals, guests reclined on couches, with positions near the host indicating status.

**"Destitute" (vv. 13, 21)**: πτωχός denotes complete poverty (beggars, those with nothing), distinct from πένης (working poor). "Poor" flattens this distinction.

**"That would be your repayment" (v. 12)**: ἀνταπόδομα suggests a transaction completed—the reciprocal invitation would close the account, leaving no room for divine reward.

**"One and all" (v. 18)**: ἀπὸ μιᾶς is an idiomatic expression meaning "unanimously" or "with one accord"—they all immediately and together began making excuses.

**"Hate" (v. 26)**: μισεῖ in Semitic idiom expresses comparative preference rather than emotional hatred (cf. Gen 29:31 LXX where Leah being "hated" means loved less than Rachel; Mal 1:2-3). However, retaining "hate" preserves the shocking rhetorical force Jesus intended; softening to "love less" would domesticate demanding language.

**"Loses its saltiness" (v. 34)**: μωρανθῇ literally means "become foolish" (same root as English "moron"), but applied to salt it means losing its essential quality. The wordplay between moral foolishness and salt becoming useless may be intentional.

**"Manure pile" (v. 35)**: κοπρία refers to dung heaps. Salt was mixed with manure to catalyze decomposition for fertilizer; salt that had lost its properties was useless even for this purpose.

verses.text: Now all the tax collectors and the sinners were drawing near to him to listen to him.
And the Pharisees and the scribes kept grumbling, saying, "This man welcomes sinners and eats with them."
So he told them this parable:
"Which man among you, having a hundred sheep and losing one of them, does not leave the ninety-nine in the wilderness and go after the lost one until he finds it?
And finding it, he places it on his shoulders, rejoicing.
And coming home, he calls together his friends and neighbors, saying to them, 'Rejoice with me, because I have found my sheep that was lost!'
I tell you, in the same way there will be more joy in heaven over one sinner who is repenting than over ninety-nine righteous people who have no need of repentance.
"Or what woman, having ten drachmas, if she loses one drachma, does not light a lamp and sweep the house and search carefully until she finds it?
And finding it, she calls together her friends and neighbors, saying, 'Rejoice with me, because I have found the drachma I had lost!'
In the same way, I tell you, there is joy in the presence of the angels of God over one sinner who is repenting."
And he said, "A certain man had two sons.
And the younger of them said to his father, 'Father, give me the share of the property that falls to me.' So he divided his livelihood between them.
And not many days later, the younger son gathered everything together and traveled to a distant country, and there he squandered his property living dissolutely.
And when he had spent everything, a severe famine came upon that country, and he began to be in want.
So he went and attached himself to one of the citizens of that country, who sent him into his fields to feed pigs.
And he was longing to fill his belly with the carob pods that the pigs were eating, but no one was giving him anything.
But coming to himself, he said, 'How many of my father's hired workers have more than enough bread, while I am perishing here from hunger!
I will rise and go to my father, and I will say to him: Father, I have sinned against heaven and before you.
I am no longer worthy to be called your son. Make me like one of your hired workers.'
And he rose and went to his father. But while he was still far off, his father saw him and was moved in his gut, and running, he fell upon his neck and kissed him again and again.
And the son said to him, 'Father, I have sinned against heaven and before you. I am no longer worthy to be called your son.'
But the father said to his servants, 'Quickly! Bring out the finest robe and clothe him, and put a ring on his hand and sandals on his feet.
And bring the fattened calf—slaughter it—and let us eat and celebrate!
For this son of mine was dead and has come back to life; he was lost and has been found.' And they began to celebrate.
Now his elder son was in the field. And as he was coming and drew near the house, he heard music and dancing.
And summoning one of the servants, he asked what this might be.
And he told him, 'Your brother has come, and your father has slaughtered the fattened calf, because he has received him back safe and sound.'
But he became angry and refused to go in. So his father came out and was pleading with him.

But he answered his father, 'Look! All these years I have been slaving for you, and I have never disobeyed a command of yours, yet you never gave me even a young goat so I could celebrate with my friends.
But when this son of yours came—the one who devoured your livelihood with prostitutes—you slaughtered the fattened calf for him!'
But he said to him, 'Child, you are always with me, and everything that is mine is yours.
But we had to celebrate and rejoice, because this brother of yours was dead and has come to life; he was lost and has been found.'"

chapters.notes:
**"Kept grumbling" (v. 2)**: The Greek διεγόγγυζον is an intensive form (the δια- prefix intensifies) in the imperfect tense, indicating ongoing, persistent complaining. This is the same verb used of Israel's grumbling in the wilderness (LXX), creating an implicit comparison.

**"Was moved in his gut" (v. 20)**: The Greek ἐσπλαγχνίσθη derives from σπλάγχνα (intestines/bowels), the seat of deep emotion in ancient physiology. "Moved with compassion" is accurate but loses the visceral, bodily nature of the response. This is a profoundly physical reaction.

**"Kissed him again and again" (v. 20)**: The Greek κατεφίλησεν uses the κατα- prefix as an intensifier, and the verb itself already conveys affection. This is emphatic, repeated, or fervent kissing—not a single formal kiss.

**"Living dissolutely" (v. 13)**: The adverb ἀσώτως comes from ἄσωτος (literally "unsavable"), describing reckless, wasteful living. "Prodigal" has become so associated with this parable that it has lost descriptive force. "Dissolutely" captures the moral dimension of wastefulness.

**"Attached himself" (v. 15)**: The Greek ἐκολλήθη means literally "glued himself to"—language of desperate clinging. The Jewish son reducing himself to tending pigs (unclean animals) for a Gentile would have been shocking to the original audience.

**"Coming to himself" (v. 17)**: The idiom εἰς ἑαυτὸν ἐλθών means "coming to one's senses." This phrase marks the turning point—a moment of self-awareness and recognition.

**"Slaving for you" (v. 29)**: The elder son uses δουλεύω (to serve as a slave), revealing his perception of his relationship with his father—servitude rather than sonship. This is thematically crucial: he has been in the father's house all along but has understood himself as a slave, not a son.

**"This son of yours" / "this brother of yours" (vv. 30, 32)**: The elder son refuses to say "my brother," using the distancing phrase "this son of yours." The father gently corrects him: "this brother of yours"—insisting on the relationship.

**"We had to" (v. 32)**: The Greek ἔδει expresses necessity—"it was necessary." The celebration was not optional but morally imperative given what had occurred.

verses.text: He was also speaking to his disciples: "There was a certain rich man who had an estate manager, and this manager was accused before him of squandering his possessions.
So he summoned him and said to him, 'What is this I hear about you? Hand over the account of your management, for you can no longer be manager.'
The manager said to himself, 'What am I going to do, since my master is taking the management away from me? I am not strong enough to dig, and I am ashamed to beg.
I know what I will do, so that when I am removed from the management, people will welcome me into their homes.'
"And summoning each one of his master's debtors, he said to the first, 'How much do you owe my master?'
He said, 'A hundred baths of olive oil.' He said to him, 'Take your contract, sit down quickly, and write fifty.'
Then he said to another, 'And you—how much do you owe?' He said, 'A hundred cors of wheat.' He said to him, 'Take your contract and write eighty.'
"And the master commended the dishonest manager because he had acted shrewdly. For the children of this age are shrewder than the children of light in dealing with their own generation.
And I tell you: Make friends for yourselves by means of dishonest wealth, so that when it runs out, they may welcome you into the eternal dwellings.
"The one who is faithful in a very small matter is also faithful in much, and the one who is dishonest in a very small matter is also dishonest in much.
So if you have not been faithful with dishonest wealth, who will entrust to you what is truly valuable?
And if you have not been faithful with what belongs to another, who will give you what is your own?
"No household servant can serve two masters. For either he will hate the one and love the other, or he will be devoted to the one and despise the other. You cannot serve God and Wealth."
Now the Pharisees, who were lovers of money, were listening to all these things, and they were sneering at him.
And he said to them, "You are the ones who declare yourselves righteous before people, but God knows your hearts. For what is exalted among humans is an abomination before God.
"The Law and the Prophets were until John. From then on, the kingdom of God is being proclaimed as good news, and everyone is pressing forcefully into it.
But it is easier for heaven and earth to pass away than for one stroke of a letter in the Law to fall.
"Everyone who divorces his wife and marries another commits adultery, and the one who marries a woman divorced from her husband commits adultery.
"Now there was a certain rich man who dressed himself in purple and fine linen, feasting lavishly every day.
And a poor man named Lazarus had been laid at his gate, covered with sores,
longing to be filled with what fell from the rich man's table. Even the dogs would come and lick his sores.
"Now it happened that the poor man died and was carried away by the angels to Abraham's side. The rich man also died and was buried.
And in Hades, lifting up his eyes while being in torment, he sees Abraham far off and Lazarus at his side.
And he called out and said, 'Father Abraham, have mercy on me! Send Lazarus to dip the tip of his finger in water and cool my tongue, for I am in anguish in this flame.'
"But Abraham said, 'Child, remember that you received your good things during your life, and Lazarus likewise the bad things. But now here he is being comforted, while you are in anguish.
And besides all this, a great chasm has been fixed between us and you, so that those wanting to cross over from here to you are not able, nor can anyone cross over from there to us.'
"And he said, 'Then I beg you, father, send him to my father's house—
for I have five brothers—so that he may warn them thoroughly, lest they also come to this place of torment.'
"But Abraham says, 'They have Moses and the Prophets. Let them listen to them.'
"But he said, 'No, Father Abraham! But if someone goes to them from the dead, they will repent.'
"He said to him, 'If they do not listen to Moses and the Prophets, neither will they be convinced even if someone rises from the dead.'"

chapters.notes:
**"Estate manager" / "manager" (v. 1-8)**: Greek οἰκονόμος refers to a trusted servant who managed a household or estate's affairs—finances, property, and personnel. "Steward" is archaic; "manager" captures the role while "estate manager" specifies the context.

**"Contract" (v. 6, 7)**: Greek τὰ γράμματα literally means "the writings" but here refers specifically to the debt document or promissory note. "Contract" conveys the legal-commercial nature better than the vague "bill."

**"Baths" and "cors" (v. 6, 7)**: These are Hebrew/Aramaic measures transliterated into Greek (βάτος, κόρος). A bath was approximately 8-9 gallons; a cor was roughly 10-12 bushels. The oil debt reduction (50%) and wheat reduction (20%) likely represent the manager forgiving his own commission, making his action shrewd but possibly not strictly theft.

**"Dishonest wealth" (v. 9, 11)**: Greek μαμωνᾶ τῆς ἀδικίας is literally "mammon of unrighteousness." μαμωνᾶς is an Aramaic loanword for wealth/property. The genitive "of unrighteousness" characterizes wealth as inherently tainted by this world's corrupt systems, not that it was necessarily acquired dishonestly.

**"Children of this age... children of light" (v. 8)**: The phrase υἱοὶ τοῦ αἰῶνος τούτου and υἱοὺς τοῦ φωτός uses the Semitic idiom "sons of X" meaning "those who belong to/are characterized by X." This terminology appears also in the Dead Sea Scrolls.

**"Sneering" (v. 14)**: Greek ἐξεμυκτήριζον derives from μυκτήρ (nose)—literally "turning up the nose." This captures contemptuous mockery more vividly than "scoffed" or "ridiculed."

**"Abomination" (v. 15)**: Greek βδέλυγμα is a strong term used in the LXX especially for idolatry and things detestable to God. The point is that what humans value highly (social status, wealth) God regards as he regards idols.

**"Pressing forcefully into it" (v. 16)**: Greek βιάζεται (middle voice) has been debated—does it mean people are forcing their way in (positive urgency) or the kingdom is being attacked? The middle voice and context suggest eager, forceful entry.

**"Abraham's side" (v. 22, 23)**: Greek κόλπος literally means "bosom" or "chest" but idiomatically refers to the place of honor at a banquet, reclining next to the host. This evokes the eschatological banquet imagery—Lazarus now holds the position of honor beside Abraham.

**"Hades" (v. 23)**: I retain "Hades" (ᾅδης) rather than "hell" because first-century Jewish hearers would understand this as the realm of the dead, not the later Christian concept of eternal punishment. The narrative draws on Jewish traditions about the afterlife's geography.

**"Rises from the dead" (v. 31)**: Greek ἀναστῇ (from ἀνίστημι) specifically means "rise/stand up"—the standard resurrection vocabulary. For Luke's audience, this final line would carry profound irony given Jesus's own resurrection and the continued unbelief it encountered.

verses.text: Then he said to his disciples: "It is impossible for stumbling blocks not to come, but woe to the one through whom they come!
It would be better for him if a millstone were hung around his neck and he were thrown into the sea than for him to cause one of these little ones to stumble.
Watch yourselves. If your brother sins, rebuke him, and if he repents, forgive him.
And if he sins against you seven times in a day and seven times returns to you saying, 'I repent,' you will forgive him."
And the apostles said to the Lord, "Increase our faith!"
But the Lord said, "If you had faith like a mustard seed, you would say to this mulberry tree, 'Be uprooted and planted in the sea,' and it would obey you.
"Which of you who has a slave plowing or tending sheep will say to him when he comes in from the field, 'Come right over and recline at the table'?
Will he not rather say to him, 'Prepare something for me to eat, and dress yourself for service and wait on me while I eat and drink, and after that you may eat and drink'?
Does he owe gratitude to the slave because he did what was commanded?
So also you, when you have done everything commanded of you, say, 'We are slaves who have earned nothing extra; we have only done what we were obligated to do.'"
And it happened that while he was traveling to Jerusalem, he was passing through the border region between Samaria and Galilee.
As he was entering a certain village, ten men with skin diseases met him, and they stood at a distance.
They raised their voices, saying, "Jesus, Master, have mercy on us!"
When he saw them, he said, "Go and show yourselves to the priests." And it happened that as they went, they were cleansed.
But one of them, when he saw that he was healed, turned back, glorifying God with a loud voice.
He fell on his face at Jesus's feet, giving him thanks. And he was a Samaritan.
Jesus responded and said, "Were not ten cleansed? Where then are the nine?
Was no one found to return and give glory to God except this foreigner?"
And he said to him, "Rise and go your way. Your faith has saved you."
When he was asked by the Pharisees when the kingdom of God was coming, he answered them and said, "The kingdom of God does not come through careful observation,
nor will they say, 'Look, here it is!' or 'There!' For behold, the kingdom of God is in your midst."
Then he said to the disciples, "Days are coming when you will long to see even one of the days of the Son of Man, and you will not see it.
They will say to you, 'Look, there!' or 'Look, here!' Do not go out, do not pursue them.
For just as lightning, when it flashes, lights up the sky from one end to the other, so will the Son of Man be in his day.
But first he must suffer many things and be rejected by this generation.
"And just as it was in the days of Noah, so it will be in the days of the Son of Man:
they were eating, drinking, marrying, being given in marriage, until the day Noah entered the ark, and the flood came and destroyed them all.
Likewise, just as it was in the days of Lot: they were eating, drinking, buying, selling, planting, building—
but on the day Lot went out from Sodom, fire and sulfur rained from heaven and destroyed them all.
It will be the same on the day the Son of Man is revealed.
"On that day, whoever is on the housetop with his belongings in the house must not go down to retrieve them, and likewise the one in the field must not turn back to what is behind.
Remember Lot's wife.
Whoever seeks to preserve his life will lose it, but whoever loses it will preserve it.
I tell you, on that night there will be two in one bed—one will be taken and the other left.
There will be two women grinding together—one will be taken and the other left."
And they responded and said to him, "Where, Lord?" And he said to them, "Where the corpse is, there the vultures will gather."

chapters.notes:
**"Slaves who have earned nothing extra" (v. 10)**: The Greek ἀχρεῖοι is often translated "worthless" or "unworthy," which can sound like self-denigration. The term more precisely means "without profit" or "having produced no surplus value"—slaves who have done only what was required and thus merit no special reward. The point is not that disciples are worthless, but that obedience is baseline expectation, not grounds for commendation.

**"If you had faith" (v. 6)**: The Greek construction (εἰ + imperfect... ἂν + imperfect/aorist) is a contrary-to-fact conditional, implying "but you don't." Most translations render this as present tense ("if you have"), which loses the implicit critique.

**"In your midst" (v. 21)**: The Greek ἐντὸς ὑμῶν could mean "within you" (interior/spiritual) or "among you" (present in your midst). Given that Jesus is speaking to Pharisees, "within you" seems theologically unlikely. "Among you" suggests the kingdom is already present in Jesus himself.

**"Vultures" (v. 37)**: The Greek ἀετοί technically means "eagles," but eagles are not carrion birds. The reference to gathering around a σῶμα (corpse) indicates scavenging behavior, pointing to vultures—which ancient writers sometimes grouped with eagles.

**"Corpse" (v. 37)**: The Greek σῶμα means "body" but in context clearly refers to a dead body. Making this explicit captures the grim proverbial nature of the saying.

**"Master" (v. 13)**: The Greek ἐπιστάτα is unique to Luke and means "overseer, commander, chief"—a term of authority stronger than "teacher."

**Verse 36 omitted**: This verse, present in some manuscripts and traditional translations, is absent from the earliest and best manuscripts and represents an interpolation from Matthew 24:40.

verses.text: He was telling them a parable about the need for them to pray at all times and not lose heart.
He said: "There was a judge in a certain city who neither feared God nor had regard for any person.
And there was a widow in that city who kept coming to him saying, 'Grant me justice against my adversary.'
For a while he refused. But afterward he said to himself, 'Even though I do not fear God and have no regard for anyone,
yet because this widow keeps causing me trouble, I will grant her justice—so that she will not keep coming and wear me down completely.'"
And the Lord said, "Listen to what the unjust judge says.
Will not God bring about justice for his chosen ones who cry out to him day and night? Is he slow to act on their behalf?
I tell you, he will bring about justice for them swiftly. Yet when the Son of Man comes, will he find such faith on the earth?"
He also told this parable to some who were confident in themselves that they were righteous and who treated everyone else with contempt:
"Two men went up to the temple to pray—one a Pharisee and the other a tax collector.
The Pharisee stood and prayed these things concerning himself: 'God, I thank you that I am not like the rest of humanity—swindlers, cheaters, adulterers—or even like this tax collector.
I fast twice a week; I tithe on everything I acquire.'
"But the tax collector, standing far off, would not even lift his eyes toward heaven but kept beating his chest, saying, 'God, show mercy to me—the sinner.'
I tell you, this man went down to his home justified rather than the other. For everyone who exalts himself will be humbled, but the one who humbles himself will be exalted."
Now people were bringing even their infants to him so that he might touch them. When the disciples saw this, they began rebuking them.
But Jesus called them to himself, saying, "Let the children come to me and do not prevent them, for the kingdom of God belongs to such as these.
Truly I tell you, whoever does not receive the kingdom of God like a child will never enter it."
A certain ruler asked him, "Good Teacher, what must I do to inherit eternal life?"
Jesus said to him, "Why do you call me good? No one is good except God alone.
You know the commandments: Do not commit adultery, do not murder, do not steal, do not bear false witness, honor your father and mother."
And he said, "All these I have kept since my youth."
When Jesus heard this, he said to him, "One thing is still lacking for you: sell everything you have and distribute it to the poor, and you will have treasure in the heavens—then come, follow me."
But when he heard this, he became deeply grieved, for he was extremely wealthy.
Seeing him, Jesus said, "How difficult it is for those who have wealth to enter the kingdom of God!
For it is easier for a camel to pass through the eye of a needle than for a rich person to enter the kingdom of God."
Those who heard this said, "Then who can be saved?"
He replied, "What is impossible with humans is possible with God."
Peter said, "Look, we have left what we had and followed you."
And he said to them, "Truly I tell you, there is no one who has left house or wife or brothers or parents or children for the sake of the kingdom of God
who will not receive many times as much in this present time, and in the age to come, eternal life."
Taking the twelve aside, he said to them, "Look, we are going up to Jerusalem, and everything written through the prophets about the Son of Man will be fulfilled.
For he will be handed over to the Gentiles and will be mocked and insulted and spit upon.
After flogging him, they will kill him, and on the third day he will rise."
But they understood none of this. This saying was hidden from them, and they did not grasp what was being said.
As he drew near to Jericho, a blind man was sitting beside the road begging.
Hearing a crowd passing through, he asked what this might be.
They told him, "Jesus the Nazarene is passing by."
And he cried out, "Jesus, Son of David, have mercy on me!"
Those at the front rebuked him, telling him to be silent, but he shouted all the more, "Son of David, have mercy on me!"
Jesus stopped and ordered him to be brought to him. When he came near, he asked him,
"What do you want me to do for you?" He said, "Lord, let me see again."
And Jesus said to him, "See again. Your faith has saved you."
Immediately he could see again, and he followed him, glorifying God. And all the people, when they saw it, gave praise to God.

chapters.notes:
**"Wear me down completely" (v. 5)**: The Greek ὑπωπιάζῃ literally means "give me a black eye" or "strike me under the eye." It's vivid, almost comic language for being worn out by someone's persistence. The phrase εἰς τέλος can mean "finally" or "completely"—the judge fears being utterly exhausted by her relentless coming.

**"Is he slow to act on their behalf?" (v. 7)**: The phrase καὶ μακροθυμεῖ ἐπ' αὐτοῖς is notoriously difficult. μακροθυμέω typically means "be patient," but its function here is debated. I've rendered it as a rhetorical question expecting a negative answer, paralleling the structure of the preceding question—God will not delay.

**"Such faith" (v. 8)**: The article τὴν πίστιν may indicate "faith of this kind"—the persistent, crying-out faith exemplified in the parable.

**"Prayed these things concerning himself" (v. 11)**: The phrase πρὸς ἑαυτὸν ταῦτα is ambiguous—it could mean "by himself" (location) or "to/about himself" (the content and direction of his prayer). The latter captures the irony: his thanksgiving is really about himself, not God.

**"The sinner" (v. 13)**: The article τῷ ἁμαρτωλῷ is emphatic—not just "a sinner" but "the sinner," as if he were the only one or the chief one. It expresses profound self-awareness.

**"Show mercy" (v. 13)**: The verb ἱλάσθητι carries sacrificial overtones from LXX usage—propitiation, atonement. The tax collector appeals to God's merciful nature to cover his sin.

**"Swindlers, cheaters" (v. 11)**: ἅρπαγες (those who seize, plunder) and ἄδικοι (unrighteous, unjust) are rendered to capture the specific accusations—not just generic sinfulness but economic predation and unfair dealing.

**"Since my youth" (v. 21)**: ἐκ νεότητος refers to the age of religious responsibility (around 13), when a Jewish male became obligated to keep the commandments.

**"Your faith has saved you" (v. 42)**: σέσωκέν encompasses both physical healing and spiritual salvation—the ambiguity is intentional in Greek and should be preserved.

verses.text: And having entered Jericho, he was passing through it.
And look—a man called by the name Zacchaeus. He was a chief tax collector, and he was wealthy.
He was trying to see who Jesus was, but he could not because of the crowd, since he was short in stature.
So he ran ahead and climbed up into a sycamore-fig tree to see him, because Jesus was about to pass that way.
And when Jesus came to that spot, he looked up and said to him, "Zacchaeus, hurry and come down, for today I must stay at your house."
And he hurried down and welcomed him with joy.
When they saw this, everyone began grumbling, saying, "He has gone in to be the guest of a sinful man."
But Zacchaeus stood and said to the Lord, "Look, Lord—half of my possessions I am giving to the poor, and if I have extorted anything from anyone, I am paying back four times as much."
And Jesus said to him, "Today salvation has come to this house, because he too is a son of Abraham.
For the Son of Man came to seek and to save the lost."
While they were listening to these things, he went on to tell a parable, because he was near Jerusalem and they supposed that the kingdom of God was about to appear immediately.
So he said: "A certain man of noble birth traveled to a distant country to receive a kingdom for himself and then return.
He called ten of his slaves and gave them ten minas, and told them, 'Do business with this until I come back.'
But his citizens hated him and sent a delegation after him, saying, 'We do not want this man to reign over us.'
"When he returned, having received the kingdom, he ordered these slaves to whom he had given the money to be summoned to him, so that he might learn what they had gained by trading.
The first came forward and said, 'Master, your mina has earned ten more minas.'
And he said to him, 'Well done, good slave! Because you proved faithful in a very small matter, you shall have authority over ten cities.'
And the second came, saying, 'Your mina, master, has made five minas.'
And he said to this one also, 'You shall be over five cities.'
"Then another came, saying, 'Master, here is your mina, which I kept put away in a cloth.
For I was afraid of you, because you are a harsh man—you withdraw what you did not deposit and harvest what you did not sow.'
He said to him, 'By your own words I will judge you, wicked slave. You knew that I am a harsh man, withdrawing what I did not deposit and harvesting what I did not sow?
Then why did you not put my money in the bank? And when I came I would have collected it with interest.'
And to those standing by he said, 'Take the mina from him and give it to the one who has the ten minas.'
And they said to him, 'Master, he already has ten minas!'
'I tell you, to everyone who has, more will be given; but from the one who does not have, even what he has will be taken away.
But as for these enemies of mine who did not want me to reign over them—bring them here and slaughter them in front of me.'"
After saying these things, he went on ahead, going up to Jerusalem.
And when he drew near to Bethphage and Bethany, at the mount called Olivet, he sent two of the disciples,
saying, "Go into the village opposite you, and as you enter it you will find a colt tied, on which no human being has ever sat. Untie it and bring it here.
And if anyone asks you, 'Why are you untying it?' you shall say this: 'The Lord has need of it.'"
Those who were sent went off and found it just as he had told them.
As they were untying the colt, its owners said to them, "Why are you untying the colt?"
And they said, "The Lord has need of it."
And they brought it to Jesus, and throwing their cloaks on the colt, they set Jesus upon it.
As he went along, people kept spreading their cloaks on the road.
As he was now approaching the descent of the Mount of Olives, the whole crowd of disciples began to rejoice and praise God with a loud voice for all the mighty works they had seen,
saying, "Blessed is the king who comes in the name of the Lord! Peace in heaven and glory in the highest!"
And some of the Pharisees from the crowd said to him, "Teacher, rebuke your disciples."
And he answered, "I tell you, if these become silent, the stones will cry out."
And as he drew near, seeing the city, he wept over it,
saying, "If you had known on this day—even you—the things that make for peace! But now they have been hidden from your eyes.
For days will come upon you when your enemies will throw up a siege wall around you and encircle you and hem you in on every side.
They will dash you to the ground—you and your children within you—and they will not leave one stone upon another in you, because you did not recognize the time of your visitation."
And entering the temple, he began to drive out those who were selling,
saying to them, "It is written, 'My house shall be a house of prayer,' but you have made it a den of bandits."
And he was teaching daily in the temple. The chief priests and the scribes and the leading men of the people were seeking to destroy him,
but they could not find a way to do it, for all the people hung on his every word.

chapters.notes:
**"Chief tax collector" (v. 2)**: ἀρχιτελώνης is a hapax legomenon—this is its only occurrence in ancient Greek literature. The prefix ἀρχι- indicates a supervisor or chief. This was likely someone who contracted with Rome for tax collection rights and employed other tax collectors under him, making him both wealthy and doubly despised.

**"Extorted" (v. 8)**: ἐσυκοφάντησα means to make false accusations for gain or to extort through intimidation—a specific form of corruption associated with tax collectors who could threaten people with inflated assessments. "Cheated" or "defrauded" are too generic.

**"Four times as much" (v. 8)**: This exceeds the standard Torah requirement for restitution (principal plus 20%, per Leviticus 6:5), matching instead the penalty for theft of livestock (Exodus 22:1). Zacchaeus offers the maximum possible restitution.

**"Minas" (v. 13ff)**: A mina was worth about 100 drachmas—roughly 100 days' wages for a laborer. This is far less than the talents in Matthew 25's similar parable, making the story more about faithfulness in ordinary matters than about vast wealth.

**"Do business with this" (v. 13)**: Πραγματεύσασθε is commercial language—"trade" or "conduct business." The master expects profit, not mere preservation.

**"Harsh" (v. 21-22)**: αὐστηρός means severe, exacting, strict—someone difficult to please. "Harsh" captures the servant's perception of the master as unreasonably demanding.

**"The bank" (v. 23)**: τράπεζαν literally means "table"—specifically a money-changer's table. This was the ancient equivalent of depositing money at interest.

**"Slaughter" (v. 27)**: κατασφάξατε is a violent word—to cut down, butcher, slay. The parable's ending is deliberately shocking.

**"If you had known... the things that make for peace!" (v. 42)**: The sentence breaks off unfinished (aposiopesis), a rhetorical device expressing overwhelming emotion. Jesus cannot bring himself to complete the thought of what might have been.

**"The time of your visitation" (v. 44)**: ἐπισκοπή means a divine visit—God coming to inspect, help, or judge. The term carries the weight of God's presence coming to his people, whether for salvation or judgment. Jerusalem failed to recognize that this moment of divine visitation had arrived.

**"Den of bandits" (v. 46)**: λῃστῶν refers to bandits or robbers (not petty thieves), echoing Jeremiah 7:11 LXX. The image is of criminals using a hideout—the temple has become a place where exploitation is sheltered rather than confronted.

**"Hung on his every word" (v. 48)**: ἐξεκρέματο is vivid—literally "hung from him." The people were so captivated they were suspended on his words, making it impossible for the authorities to act.

verses.text: On one of those days, while he was teaching the people in the temple and proclaiming the good news, the chief priests and the scribes, together with the elders, came and stood before him.
They spoke to him, saying, "Tell us—by what authority are you doing these things? Or who is the one who gave you this authority?"
He answered them, "I will also ask you a question. Tell me:
The baptism of John—was it from heaven, or from human beings?"
They deliberated among themselves, saying, "If we say, 'From heaven,' he will say, 'Why did you not believe him?'
But if we say, 'From human beings,' all the people will stone us, for they are convinced that John was a prophet."
So they answered that they did not know where it was from.
And Jesus said to them, "Neither will I tell you by what authority I am doing these things."
Then he began to tell the people this parable: "A man planted a vineyard and leased it to tenant farmers, and went away for a long time.
At the proper season, he sent a slave to the tenant farmers so that they would give him his share of the vineyard's fruit. But the tenant farmers beat him and sent him away empty-handed.
He proceeded to send another slave, and they beat that one also and treated him shamefully and sent him away empty-handed.
He proceeded to send a third, and this one too they wounded and threw out.
"Then the owner of the vineyard said, 'What shall I do? I will send my beloved son. Perhaps they will show him respect.'
But when the tenant farmers saw him, they reasoned among themselves, saying, 'This is the heir. Let us kill him so that the inheritance may become ours.'
And they threw him out of the vineyard and killed him. "What then will the owner of the vineyard do to them?
He will come and destroy those tenant farmers and give the vineyard to others." When they heard this, they said, "May it never be!"
But he looked directly at them and said, "Then what is this that has been written: 'The stone that the builders rejected— this has become the cornerstone'?
Everyone who falls on that stone will be shattered, but on whomever it falls, it will crush him to dust."
The scribes and the chief priests sought to lay hands on him in that very hour, but they feared the people, for they recognized that he had told this parable against them.
So, watching for an opportunity, they sent agents who pretended to be righteous, in order to catch him in something he said, so as to hand him over to the rule and authority of the governor.
They questioned him, saying, "Teacher, we know that you speak and teach correctly, and you do not show partiality to anyone, but teach the way of God in truth.
Is it lawful for us to pay tribute to Caesar, or not?"
But perceiving their craftiness, he said to them,
"Show me a denarius. Whose image and inscription does it have?" They answered, "Caesar's."
He said to them, "Then give back to Caesar what belongs to Caesar, and to God what belongs to God."
They were unable to catch him in his words before the people, and marveling at his answer, they fell silent.
Then some of the Sadducees—those who deny that there is a resurrection—approached and questioned him,
saying, "Teacher, Moses wrote for us that if a man's brother dies having a wife, and he is childless, the brother should take the wife and raise up offspring for his brother.
Now there were seven brothers. The first took a wife and died childless.
And the second
and the third took her, and likewise all seven left no children and died.
Finally, the woman also died.
In the resurrection, therefore, whose wife does she become? For all seven had her as wife."
Jesus said to them, "The children of this age marry and are given in marriage,
but those who are considered worthy to attain to that age and to the resurrection from the dead neither marry nor are given in marriage.
For they can no longer die, since they are equal to angels and are children of God, being children of the resurrection.
But that the dead are raised—even Moses revealed this at the bush, when he speaks of the Lord as 'the God of Abraham and the God of Isaac and the God of Jacob.'
Now he is not God of the dead but of the living, for to him all are alive."
Some of the scribes responded, "Teacher, you have spoken well."
For they no longer dared to ask him anything.
Then he said to them, "How can they say that the Messiah is David's son?
For David himself says in the book of Psalms: 'The Lord said to my Lord, "Sit at my right hand
until I make your enemies a footstool for your feet."'
David therefore calls him 'Lord'—so how is he his son?"
While all the people were listening, he said to his disciples,
"Beware of the scribes who desire to walk around in long robes and love greetings in the marketplaces and the best seats in the synagogues and the places of honor at banquets—
who devour the houses of widows and for a pretense make long prayers. These will receive greater condemnation."

chapters.notes:
**"Proceeded to send" (vv. 11-12)**: The Greek προσέθετο πέμψαι is a Semitic idiom (literally "added to send"), reflecting Hebrew/Aramaic narrative style where וַיֹּסֶף ("and he added") indicates continuation of action. "Proceeded to send" captures this sequential emphasis better than simply "sent again."

**"Show him respect" (v. 13)**: ἐντραπήσονται carries the sense of being ashamed before someone, showing deference or reverence. "Respect" conveys this relational dynamic.

**"Crush him to dust" (v. 18)**: λικμήσει is a winnowing term—scattering like chaff in the wind. The image is of complete pulverization and dispersal, stronger than mere crushing.

**"Agents" (v. 20)**: ἐγκαθέτους means those planted covertly, infiltrators or spies. "Agents" captures the sense of being deliberately placed by the authorities.

**"Do not show partiality" (v. 21)**: οὐ λαμβάνεις πρόσωπον is a literal calque of the Hebrew idiom נָשָׂא פָנִים ("lift the face"), meaning to show favoritism based on someone's status.

**"Give back" (v. 25)**: ἀπόδοτε means "render" or "pay back what is owed," not simply "give." It implies returning what already belongs to someone.

**"At the bush" (v. 37)**: ἐπὶ τῆς βάτου is a way of citing scripture by referring to a passage—"in the section about the bush" (Exodus 3).

**"Children of this age" / "children of the resurrection" (vv. 34, 36)**: υἱοί in these phrases is idiomatic, meaning "those who belong to" or "those characterized by"—a Semitic construction.

verses.text: Looking up, he saw the wealthy putting their gifts into the treasury.
He also saw a destitute widow putting in two small copper coins.
And he said, "Truly I tell you, this poor widow has put in more than all of them.
For all these put in their gifts out of their surplus, but she out of her poverty put in all the livelihood she had."
As some were speaking about the temple—how it was adorned with beautiful stones and sacred offerings—he said,
"These things you are looking at—days will come when not one stone will be left upon another that will not be thrown down."
They asked him, "Teacher, when will these things be? And what will be the sign when these things are about to happen?"
He said, "Watch out that you are not led astray. For many will come in my name saying, 'I am he,' and 'The time has drawn near.' Do not follow after them.
When you hear of wars and upheavals, do not be terrified. For these things must happen first, but the end does not come immediately."
Then he was saying to them, "Nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom.
There will be great earthquakes, and famines and plagues in various places, and there will be terrifying events and great signs from heaven.
"But before all these things, they will lay their hands on you and persecute you, handing you over to synagogues and prisons, bringing you before kings and governors on account of my name.
This will result in an opportunity for testimony.
So resolve in your hearts not to rehearse your defense beforehand,
for I will give you words and wisdom that none of your adversaries will be able to resist or contradict.
You will be handed over even by parents and brothers and relatives and friends, and they will put some of you to death.
You will be hated by all on account of my name.
Yet not a hair from your head will perish.
By your endurance you will gain your lives.
"When you see Jerusalem being surrounded by armies, then know that her desolation has drawn near.
Then let those in Judea flee to the mountains, let those inside the city depart, and let those in the countryside not enter her.
For these are days of vengeance, so that all that is written may be fulfilled.
How terrible for those who are pregnant and for those who are nursing in those days! For there will be great distress upon the land and wrath against this people.
They will fall by the edge of the sword and be taken captive to all the nations, and Jerusalem will be trampled by the nations until the times of the nations are fulfilled.
"And there will be signs in sun and moon and stars, and on the earth anguish among nations, perplexed at the roaring of the sea and the surging waves,
people fainting from fear and dread of what is coming upon the world. For the powers of the heavens will be shaken.
And then they will see the Son of Man coming in a cloud with power and great glory.
When these things begin to happen, stand up and raise your heads, because your liberation is drawing near."
And he told them a parable: "Look at the fig tree and all the trees.
When they have already sprouted, you see for yourselves and know that summer is already near.
So also you, when you see these things happening, know that the kingdom of God is near.
Truly I tell you, this generation will certainly not pass away until all things have happened.
Heaven and earth will pass away, but my words will never pass away.
"But watch yourselves, lest your hearts be weighed down with carousing and drunkenness and the anxieties of life, and that day come upon you suddenly
like a trap. For it will come upon all who dwell on the face of the whole earth.
Stay alert at all times, praying that you may have strength to escape all these things that are about to happen and to stand before the Son of Man."
During the days he was teaching in the temple, but at night he would go out and stay on the mount called Olivet.
And all the people would come to him early in the morning in the temple to hear him.

chapters.notes:
**"Destitute" (v. 2) / "poor" (v. 3)**: Luke uses two different Greek words: πενιχρός in v. 2 (a rarer term suggesting neediness) and πτωχός in v. 3 (often used for beggars). "Destitute" captures the more emphatic sense of the first term.

**"All the livelihood she had" (v. 4)**: The Greek βίος here means not merely "life" in the abstract but one's means of living—resources for survival. This is stronger than "all she had to live on"; it was her entire economic existence.

**"Sacred offerings" (v. 5)**: The Greek ἀναθήμασιν refers to votive offerings—gifts dedicated to the deity. "Sacred offerings" captures both the religious and material dimensions.

**"Upheavals" (v. 9)**: The Greek ἀκαταστασίας denotes disorder, instability, tumult—civil unrest rather than merely "revolutions" or "insurrections."

**"Rehearse" (v. 14)**: The Greek προμελετᾶν means to practice or prepare beforehand, as one would rehearse a speech. This captures the sense better than simply "prepare."

**"Words" (v. 15)**: Literally "mouth" (στόμα), but the meaning is the words or speech that proceed from the mouth. "Words and wisdom" forms a natural pair.

**"Liberation" (v. 28)**: The Greek ἀπολύτρωσις carries connotations of release, deliverance, ransom. While "redemption" is traditional, "liberation" emphasizes the concrete rescue being described.

**"Carousing" (v. 34)**: The Greek κραιπάλῃ specifically refers to the aftereffects of excessive drinking—a hangover or the dissipation that follows a drinking bout. Paired with "drunkenness," it paints a picture of excess.

**"Times of the nations" (v. 24)**: This phrase καιροὶ ἐθνῶν is distinctive to Luke and suggests a period during which Gentile dominion over Jerusalem will continue until its appointed completion.

verses.text: Now the Festival of Unleavened Bread, the one called Passover, was drawing near.
And the chief priests and the scribes were seeking how they might do away with him, for they feared the people.
Then Satan entered into Judas, the one called Iscariot, who was of the number of the twelve.
And going away, he conferred with the chief priests and temple captains about how he might hand him over to them.
And they were delighted and agreed to give him silver.
And he consented, and began looking for an opportune moment to hand him over to them apart from the crowd.
Then came the day of Unleavened Bread, on which the Passover lamb had to be sacrificed.
And he sent Peter and John, saying, "Go and prepare the Passover for us, so that we may eat it."
And they said to him, "Where do you want us to prepare it?"
And he said to them, "Look, when you enter the city, a man carrying a clay jar of water will meet you. Follow him into the house that he enters.
And you will say to the master of the house, 'The Teacher says to you: Where is the guest room where I may eat the Passover with my disciples?'
And he will show you a large upper room, furnished. Prepare it there."
And having gone, they found it just as he had told them, and they prepared the Passover.
And when the hour came, he reclined at table, and the apostles with him.
And he said to them, "With deep longing I have longed to eat this Passover with you before I suffer.
For I tell you, I will certainly not eat it until it is fulfilled in the kingdom of God."
And having received a cup and given thanks, he said, "Take this and divide it among yourselves.
For I tell you, I will certainly not drink from now on from the fruit of the vine until the kingdom of God comes."
And having taken bread and given thanks, he broke it and gave it to them, saying, "This is my body, which is being given for you. Do this in remembrance of me."
And the cup likewise, after supper, saying, "This cup is the new covenant in my blood, which is being poured out for you."
"But look—the hand of the one betraying me is with me on the table.
For the Son of Man goes as it has been determined, but woe to that man through whom he is betrayed."
And they began to discuss among themselves which of them it might be who was about to do this.
A dispute also arose among them as to which of them was considered to be greatest.
And he said to them, "The kings of the nations lord it over them, and those who hold power over them are called 'Benefactors.'
But not so with you. Rather, let the greatest among you become like the youngest, and the one who leads like the one who serves.
